Solution to Question 1:
The 1st and 2nd branchial arches give rise to the pinna (auricle) through six mesenchymal proliferation. These proliferations are called auricular hillocks and they fuse to form the auricle.
The tissue from the second arch forms nearly all of the pinna.
The tissue from the first arch forms the tragus and external auditory meatus. Image showing the development of pinna:

Solution to Question 2:
The given image showing the presence of sinus seen between the tragus and crus of the helix is suggestive of the preauricular sinus. It is due to improper fusion of the auricular tubercle formed from the first and second arches.
The preauricular sinus is apparent at birth and is usually bilateral. There may be occasional sebaceous discharge from the punctum. It does not regress spontaneously.
Solution to Question 3:
Reconstructive surgeries for congenital malformations of the pinna (auricle) are usually performed around 5 or 6 years of age. Autologous cartilages from ribs are harvested for these purposes and the ideal timing is between 6-10 years.
At around 3 years of age, 85% of the auricular growth is complete and the cartilaginous growth is almost complete by 5 years. Surgery performed on the auricle after 5 years doesn't hinder further growth.
Solution to Question 4:
Invagination of the first pharyngeal arch gives rise to the external auditory meatus.
Previously, it was believed that the external auditory meatus develops from the first pharyngeal cleft. But recent studies suggest that the first pharyngeal arch gives rise to the external auditory meatus.
Solution to Question 5:
Given clinical scenario is suggestive of a collaural fistula, and the first branchial cleft is abnormal here.
The fistula has two openings:
One situated in the neck just below and behind the angle of mandible and
The other one in the external canal or the middle ear.
The track of the fistula traverses through the parotid in close relation to the facial nerve.

Solution to Question 7:
The eustachian tube develops from the first pharyngeal pouch.
Initially, the first pharyngeal pouch forms the tubotympanic recess. The distal part of this recess widens to form the middle ear cavity. The proximal part forms the eustachian tube.
Solution to Question 8:
The first pharyngeal arch gives rise to malleus and incus.
Stapes superstructure is formed from the second arch whereas the stapes footplate develops from the otic capsule.
Solution to Question 9:
The stapes develop from the second arch, except for its footplate and annular ligament, which develop from the otic capsule.
Solution to Question 10:
Ear ossicles attain adult size before birth. The development of the middle ear:
The ossicles are full-sized cartilage models by 15 weeks of gestation.
Endochondral ossification is complete by 25 weeks.
The middle ear is adult-sized at birth.
Solution to Question 11:
The mastoid does not reach adult size at birth. It develops fully by 2 years of age.
In infants and children up to 2 years of age, the mastoid process is not developed completely. So, the facial nerve lies just beneath the skin near its exit. Hence, during surgical procedures, the incision is given slanting posteriorly, avoiding the lower part of the mastoid. This spares the facial nerve.
Solution to Question 12:
The persistence of the petrosquamous suture is called Korner’s septum and it is responsible for the difficulty in locating the mastoid antrum and the deeper cells.
Korner’s septum separates superficial squamosal cells from the deep petrosal cells.
Incomplete removal of disease at mastoidectomy can occur if Korner’s septum is not identified. Mastoid antrum cannot be reached unless the Korner’s septum has been removed.

Solution to Question 13:
The saccule develops from pars inferior.
The development of the inner ear begins in the 3rd week of fetal life and is completed by the 16th week. The surface ectoderm on each side of the rhombencephalon thickens to form otic/auditory placodes, which then invaginate to form the otic vesicle (otocysts).
The cells of the otic vesicle differentiate to form ganglion cells, which later develop into the vestibulocochlear ganglia. Later each otic vesicle divides into a dorsal component called pars superior and a ventral component called pars inferior.
Pars superior gives rise to the utricle, semicircular canals, and endolymphatic ducts. Pars inferior gives rise to saccule and cochlear duct. The saccule is connected to the cochlea through a narrow duct called ductus reuniens.
Solution to Question 14:
The inner ear develops from 14 ossification centres.
Solution to Question 15:
The fetus starts hearing in the womb of the mother by 20 weeks of gestation due to sufficient development of the cochlea.

Solution to Question 1:
The pinna and the external auditory canal are made up of yellow elastic cartilage. It is also called the auricular cartilage.
Solution to Question 2:
I cisura terminalis cannot be used to harvest cartilage as it is devoid of cartilage.
It is the part of the pinna between the tragus and the crus of helix. Being devoid of cartilage, the incision for endaural approach for ear surgery can be made here.
The lobule is also devoid of cartilage. Hence, it is the safest site for piercing. The parts of the pinna are:

Solution to Question 3:
The skin over the pinna is loosely adherent on the medial or cranial side. Hence, it is pinchable. The skin is firmly adherent to the perichondrium on the lateral side and is non-pinchable.
Solution to Question 4:
The length of the external auditory canal is about 24 mm.
It extends from the bottom of the concha to the tympanic membrane. It has two parts:
Outer cartilaginous part - 8mm
Inner bony part- 16mm

Solution to Question 5:
The pinna has to be pulled upwards, backwards and laterally to visualise the tympanic membrane. This is done to bring the bony and cartilaginous parts of the external auditory canal in alignment.
The inner bony part is directed downwards, forwards, and medially.
The outer cartilaginous part is directed upwards, backwards, and medially.
Solution to Question 6:
The outer 1/3rd is cartilaginous (8mm) and the inner 2/3rd is bony (16mm) in the external auditory canal.

Solution to Question 7:
Fissures of Santorini are the two deficiencies in the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal. They provide a pathway for the spread of parotid or superficial mastoid infections to the canal or vice versa.
The bony canal also has a deficiency called the foramen of Huschke which acts as a pathway for the spread of infections and tumours to the deep lobe of the parotid.
Solution to Question 8:
Furuncles (staphylococcal infection of the hair follicles) are seen only in the outer one-third of the canal since hair is confined to the outer canal.
Skin is also very tightly adherent to the cartilage and hence furuncles are extremely painful.

Solution to Question 9:
Ceruminous glands are modified apocrine sweat glands. They open into hair follicles &
participate in wax production.
Apocrine glands release their products by decapitation. It is a process by which membrane-bound cytoplasm from the apical surface of the cells buds off into the lumen of the duct and is secreted.
Some apocrine glands have specific names. Those on the eyelids are referred to as Moll’s glands, and those on the external auditory meatus are termed ceruminous glands.
Solution to Question 10:
The isthmus is the narrowest part of the external auditory canal (EAC).
EAC measures about 24 mm long, cartilaginous part forms the outer one-third (8 mm) and bony part forms two-third (16 mm) of the canal. Isthmus is situated 6 mm lateral to the tympanic membrane in the bony part of the EAC. Foreign bodies that go beyond the isthmus are difficult to remove and are called impacted.
Solution to Question 11:
The normal tympanic membrane is pearly grey in color. It is thin and semitranslucent.

Solution to Question 12:
Peripheral parts are more mobile than the central part where the handle of the malleus is attached The tympanic membrane develops from all three germinal layers. It has 3 layers –
Outer epithelial layer from ectoderm

Inner mucosal layer endoderm.

Solution to Question 1:
The part of the middle ear around the eustachian tube is referred to as the protympanum. The middle ear is divided into 3 main parts:
Epitympanum/attic- above the level of pars tensa, medial to pars flaccida, and scutum.
Mesotympanum- opposite the pars tensa
Hypotympanum- below the level of TM
Solution to Question 2:

Mesotympanum- 2 mm

The floor of the middle ear is related to the internal jugular vein. Occasionally, the floor is deficient and the jugular bulb is then covered only by fibrous tissue and a mucous membrane making it susceptible to injury during middle ear surgery.

It also extends posteriorly to form the roof of the aditus and antrum as tegmen mastoidea. The following images shows the tegmen tympani and relations of middle ear:

Solution to Question 8:
The subiculum is not a part of the lateral wall of the middle ear. It is present in the medial wall, below the sinus tympani.
The lateral wall of the middle ear separates it from the external ear. It contains:
Pars tensa lying opposite to the mesotympanum
Pars flaccida and scutum lying opposite to the epitympanum.
Scutum or lateral attic wall is a wedge-shaped bone that separates the epitympanum from the external auditory canal. It can be eroded in attic cholesteatomas.

The posterior wall is related to the 4th part, which runs from the genu (pyramid) to the stylomastoid foramen where it exits the temporal bone. It is called the mastoid or the vertical part.

Solution to Question 2:
The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the scala tympani. It allows for the electrodes to be in close proximity to the ganglion cells and their dendrites which are located in the modiolus and bony spiral lamina of the cochlea.
A cochlear implant is an electronic device for severe to profound SNHL and who cannot benefit from a hearing aid. It converts sound to an electrical signal (transduction) and delivers this to the auditory nerve. Prerequisites include an intact cochlear nerve and higher auditory pathway.
In the auditory brainstem implant, the site of the implant is the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle. It is used when the cochlear nerve is not intact.

Solution to Question 6:
Scala media is part of the membranous cochlea.

The bony cochlea is a coiled tube with 2.5 to 2.75 turns around a central pyramid of bone called modiolus.
From the modiolus laterally into the tube winding like the thread of a screw is the osseous spiral lamina.
Spiral lamina along with membranes attached to it divide the tube into 3 parts:
Scala vestibuli above
Scala media in between
Scala tympani below.
The scala vestibule & tympani are part of the bony labyrinth and are filled with perilymph. They communicate with each other at the apex called helicotrema.
Scala media is part of the membranous cochlea and contains the sensory organ of Corti with hair cells.
Solution to Question 7:

It is part of the bony labyrinth and not part of the auditory pathway. The inside of the medial wall presents with recesses & openings:

An elliptical recess, which lodges the utricle
An opening for aqueduct of vestibule
An opening for the semicircular canals

Solution to Question 8:
The medial semicircular canal does not exist.
The semicircular canals are part of the bony labyrinth. They house the semicircular ducts which are the end organs for angular momentum.
They are 3 in number:
Superior also called anterior in the X-axis
Posterior in Y-axis
Lateral also called horizontal in Z-axis.

Semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome is an inner ear abnormality where the bony covering of the semicircular canals is very thin or absent. It usually affects the superior semicircular canal but can rarely involve the posterior or lateral semicircular canals. The superior semicircular canal is present inferior to the arcuate eminence of the temporal bone.

Each semicircular canal has 2 ends, ampullated & non-ampullated which open into the vestibule. The non-ampullated ends of posterior and superior canals unite to form a common channel called crus commune.

Semicircular canals respond to angular acceleration and deceleration. The receptors are the cristae, located in the ampullated ends of the three semicircular ducts.

It passes through the vestibular aqueduct. Its terminal part is dilated to form an endolymphatic sac, which lies between the two layers of dura on the posterior surface of the petrous bone.
The scala vestibuli and scala tympani are filled with perilymph and communicate with each other at the apex of cochlea through an opening called helicotrema.

Solution to Question 21:
The terminal part of the endolymphatic duct is dilated to form an endolymphatic sac, which lies between the two layers of dura on the posterior surface of the petrous bone.
Endolymphatic sac is surgically important. It is exposed for drainage or shunt operation in Meniere’s disease.

The inner ear is supplied by labyrinthine artery, a branch of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, which is a branch of the basilar artery.

Solution to Question 1:
The external ear anomaly seen here is pre-auricular tag/appendage.
Pre-auricular tags/appendages are congenital external ear anomalies. They are seen as skin-covered pieces of cartilage anywhere between the tragus and the angle of the mouth.
The clinical features of facial asymmetry, intellectual disability, limbal dermoid, and pre-auricular tags and mixed or conductive hearing loss point to a diagnosis of Goldenhar
syndrome (oculoauriculovertebral spectrum). Clinical features include:
Hypoplasia of the malar, maxillary, and mandibular regions
Macrostomia and microtia
Preauricular and facial skin tags
Hemivertebrae (usually cervical)
Intellectual disability
Cardiac, renal, and central nervous system (CNS) anomalies
Ocular features- Limbal dermoids, upper lid notching or coloboma, microphthalmos, disc coloboma
Solution to Question 2:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of preauricular sinus seen between the tragus and crus of the helix. It is the most common congenital anomaly of the 1st branchial arch, due to the incomplete fusion of the hillocks of His that develop to form the pinna.
It can get repeatedly infected and form an abscess, which would then require excision.

Solution to Question 3:
The given image showing malformed small pinna appearing like tubercles are suggestive of microtia. It is frequently accompanied by hearing loss.
Solution to Question 4:
Protruding ears or bat ears can be corrected anytime after 6 years of age if cosmetic appearance demands. This is due to the fact that the pinna is completely developed and achieves adult configuration by the age of 6 years.
Protruding ears are caused by a large concha with poorly developed antihelix and scapha.


Solution to Question 5:
Collaural fistula traverses close to the facial nerve within the substance of the parotid. It is a congenital anomaly of 1st branchial cleft.
The fistula is between the external auditory canal and neck, where the upper opening is on the floor of the external auditory canal and the lower opening is on the neck between mandible and sternocleidomastoid.
Solution to Question 6:
The image shows a cauliflower ear deformity, which is likely due to auricular hematoma.
Auricular hematoma is a collection of blood between the auricular cartilage and its perichondrium. If left untreated, the extravasated blood may clot and then organize, resulting in a typical deformity called cauliflower ear. It is also called pugilistic or boxer’s ear.
It is often seen in boxers, wrestlers, and rugby players due to blunt trauma.
Treatment comprises of aspiration of the hematoma under strict aseptic precautions and a pressure dressing, to prevent reaccumulation. Aspiration may need to be repeated. If aspiration fails, incision and drainage should be done. All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics.
Solution to Question 7:
The avulsed pinna is preserved by peeling its skin and inserting the cartilage into the postauricular area which can be preserved for delayed reconstruction.
However, immediate reimplantation using microvascular techniques would be ideal.
If the pinna is still attached to the head by a small pedicle of skin, primary reattachment should be considered.
Solution to Question 8:
The given clinical scenario of painful, erythematous ear swelling is suggestive of perichondritis. The most common cause is trauma either iatrogenic (surgical incision) or non-iatrogenic
(laceration, hematoma). It can be due to the extension of infection from diffuse otitis externa or furuncle of the meatus. The most common organism responsible is Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
The image given below shows a patient with a cauliflower ear deformity. It is also known as perichondrial hematoma or wrestler's ear. It is usually caused by repeated episodes of trauma.

Chondrodermatitis chronica helicis is a small, nodular, tender, chronic inflammatory lesion occurring on the helix of the ear. It is shown in the image below.

Otitis externa, also called swimmer's ear, is the inflammation of the ear canal. It has the following appearance:

Solution to Question 9:
A small tender nodule in the helix in a middle-aged patient is suggestive of chondrodermatitis nodularis chronica helicis. The patient will have difficulty sleeping on the affected side.
Treatment includes excision of the lesion.
Solution to Question 10:
The given image shows a keloid of the pinna and neoadjuvant chemotherapy does not reduce its recurrence post excision.
Keloid commonly occurs following trauma. The common sites are lobule and helix. There is a high chance of recurrence after excision, which can be prevented by:
Intralesional steroids
Pre and post-operative radiotherapy
Solution to Question 11:
Patients with repeated attacks of furunculosis should be investigated for diabetes mellitus.
A furuncle is a staphylococcal infection of the hair follicle. As the hairs are confined only to the cartilaginous part of the meatus, furuncle is seen only outer one-third of EAC.
Symptoms are severe compared to signs as the skin over the EAC is tightly adherent. The tragal sign is positive and there is an obliteration of the retro auricular groove.
Treated by incision and drainage or 10% ichthammol glycerine wicks and antibiotics.
Solution to Question 12:
Swimmer’s ear is synonymous with diffuse otitis externa.
The normal pH of the external auditory canal is acidic. Any condition that makes the pH alkaline predisposes to otitis externa. This includes situations such as:
Hot & humid climate (excessive sweating) and
Prolonged swimming
Solution to Question 13:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of diffuse otitis externa following a trauma. Aural toilet remains the most effective single treatment for this condition.
All exudate and debris should be carefully removed, with special emphasis on the anteroinferior meatal recess, which forms a blind pocket and acts as a reservoir of infective secretion. The aural toilet can be done by dry mopping, suction clearance, or irrigating the canal with warm, sterile normal saline.
Further treatment modalities:
After the aural toilet is done, wicks medicated with antibiotic-steroid preparation can be used. These wicks have to be changed daily for 2 to 3 days, which thereafter can be substituted by ear drops.
Broad-spectrum systemic antibiotics are used when there is cellulitis and acute tender ymphadenitis.
Analgesics are usually a part of management, as otitis externa is associated with severe pain.
Gauze wick soaked in 10% ichthammol glycerine is used to reduce swelling.
Astringents such as aluminum acetate (8%) or silver nitrate (3%) are used to dry up an oozing meatus.
Solution to Question 14:
Otomycosis is a fungal infection of the ear canal that often occurs due to Aspergillus niger (most common), Aspergillus fumigatus, or Candida albicans.
Solution to Question 15:
The given clinical scenario along with the otoscopic image showing black-headed filamentous growth is suggestive of otomycosis by Aspergillus niger.
Irritation and itching are the most predominant symptoms of Aspergillus niger infection. Pain is predominant in Aspergillus flavus infection.
The fungal mass in otomycosis is likened to a wet blotting paper/wet newspaper appearance. The appearances of otomycosis on otoscopy and the causative organisms are:
Black-headed filamentous growth - Aspergillus niger infection
Green or brown - Aspergillus fumigatus infection
White and creamy deposit - Candida infection
Rhizopus oryzae is one of the causative agents of mucormycosis. The common clinical form of this opportunistic infection is rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis (ROCM). It is rarely implicated in otomycosis.
Solution to Question 16:
The given clinical scenario of facial paralysis along with vesicular eruptions in the external auditory canal and tympanic membrane is suggestive of Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus).
Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is caused by the reactivation of Herpes zoster in the geniculate ganglion. In most patients, there is an involvement of the trunk of the facial nerve, which results in severe facial palsy.
Often, the 8th cranial nerve is also involved, which causes hearing loss and vertigo. There may also be anesthesia of the face due to the involvement of the 5th cranial nerve.

Bell's palsy is an idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset due to a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve.

Moebius syndrome is a congenital unilateral/bilateral lower motor neuron facial nerve paralysis with abducens palsy causing limited ocular abduction.
Melkersson syndrome is an idiopathic disorder consisting of a triad of:
Facial paralysis
Swelling of lips
Fissured tongue.

Solution to Question 17:
The clinical scenario of an elderly diabetic with severe otalgia, otorrhoea, granulation tissue in the external auditory canal, and lower motor neuron facial nerve palsy indicates malignant otitis externa.
It is termed malignant, even though it is an infection, due to the high mortality rate and poor response to treatment.
Solution to Question 18:
Technetium 99 bone scan remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to follow up response to treatment. It is particularly useful when the clinical suspicion for malignant otitis externa is high but the CT scan is negative.
Features of malignant otitis externa:
Pseudomonas infection in the elderly diabetics and those on immunosuppressive drugs.
Excruciating pain, profuse discharge & granulations on the floor of the external auditory canal.
Necrosis of bone aids in the spread of infection.
Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple cranial nerve palsies.
Facial paralysis is the most common nerve palsy seen.
Mitotic figures will be normal since it is an infective and not a malignant condition.
Gallium-67 is more useful in the follow-up of the patient.
Solution to Question 19:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of eczematous otitis externa and the drug implicated is neomycin.
Eczematous otitis externa is due to hypersensitivity to infective organisms or topical ear drops such as chloromycetin or neomycin, etc. The presence of intense irritation, vesicle formation, oozing, and crusting in the canal is observed.
Management involves stopping the implicated ear drops, changing to a different combination and application of steroid cream.
Note - Otitis externa hemorrhagica is a condition characterized by the formation of haemorrhagic bullae on the tympanic membrane and deep meatus. This causes severe pain in the ear and
blood-stained discharge when the bullae rupture. It is probably viral in origin.
Solution to Question 20:
Wax or cerumen is not made up of middle ear discharge. Composition of wax:
Secretions of ceruminous glands (modified apocrine sweat glands)
Secretions of the sebaceous gland (fatty secretion)
Desquamated epithelial cells
Hair
Wax is normally expelled by the movement of the jaw during eating, talking.
Functions include antibacterial action and trapping of foreign bodies and dirt. Impacted wax causes a sensation of blockage of the ear, reduced hearing, vertigo, tinnitus.
Treatment:
Softening with ceruminolytics like 2% paradichlorobenzene, 5% sodium bicarbonate in equa parts of glycerine and water.
Syringing or instrumentation or suction clearance.
Solution to Question 21:
Ceruminous glands are modified apocrine sweat glands.
Ceruminous and sebaceous glands open into the space of the hair follicle in the external auditory canal.
Solution to Question 22:
During syringing, the pinna is pulled upwards and backward and the water jet is directed along the posterosuperior wall of the meatus. This is preferred because of two anatomical reasons:
On maneuvering the pinna to bring the EAC into a straight configuration, the posterior wall is straighter and easily accessible than the anterior wall.
The posteroinferior wall of EAC is supplied by the vagus. Direct stimulation of this can lead to sudden cardiac arrest.
Complications of syringing:
Vertigo– caloric stimulation of lateral semicircular canal if water is too hot or too cold
Rupture of the tympanic membrane
Reactivation of quiescent otitis media, if there is pre-existing perforation Contraindications for syringing:
Presence of ear infection, tympanic membrane perforation
Presence of grommet or history of ear surgery
Solution to Question 23:
Keratosis obturans is the collection of a pearly white mass of desquamated epithelial cells in the deep meatus.
The keratin plug is arranged in a lamellar fashion, not at a random pattern.
Solution to Question 24:
Keratosis obturans, by pressure effect, causes absorption of bone which causes widening (not narrowing) of the meatus leading to facial nerve palsy.
Normally, epithelium from the surface of the tympanic membrane migrates onto the posterior meatal wall. Failure of this migration, or obstruction to migration caused by wax, may lead to keratosis obturans which is the accumulation of a large plug of desquamated keratin in the external auditory meatus.
Features of keratosis obturans:
Severe otalgia
Conductive hearing loss
Thickened tympanic membrane
Keratin plug/pearly white mass occluding the cana
Widened ear canal- may lead to facial nerve paralysis
Hyperemia of canal skin, sometimes with ulcerations and granulomas
Staphylococcus aureus is the most frequent isolate.
Keratosis oburans may be associated with systemic conditions like bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis.
Solution to Question 25:
The surgery done to widen the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal is meatoplasty.
Meatoplasty is a surgical procedure that involves the removal of a crescent-shaped portion of conchal cartilage to widen the external auditory meatus. It is performed in combination with all canal wall-down procedures like modified radical and radical mastoidectomies, for easy access to the mastoid cavity for periodic inspection and cleaning.
It is also done as an isolated procedure in elderly people with sagging auricles. A
sagging auricle causes obstruction to the meatus leading to the retention of wax and difficulty in hearing.
Other options:
Option B: Tympanoplasty is the surgical reconstruction to correct damage in the middle ear and restore the integrity of the tympanic membrane for improved hearing. It is ossicular reconstruction only or ossicular reconstruction with myringoplasty.
Option C: Myringoplasty refers to the reconstruction of the tympanic membrane only. Option D: Otoplasty is the correction of external ear/deformities of the pinna.
Solution to Question 26:
Meatoplasty is not a part of canal wall-up (CWU) procedures as the meatus appears normal.
However, meatoplasty is performed in combination with all canal wall down procedures like modified radical and radical mastoidectomies, for the treatment of middle ear disease such as cholesteatoma. The widened meatus helps to easily visualize and access the mastoid cavity for periodic inspection and cleaning.
It is also done in atresia/stenosis to recanalize the ear and in tortuous canals post-tympanoplasty to improve hearing.

The normal tympanic membrane is concave to the EAC with the maximum concavity at the umbo. Features of normal TM:

Mobile with change in middle ear pressures

Solution to Question 1:
The eustachian tube is the most common route of infection in acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM).
The infection travels via the lumen of the tube or along subepithelial peritubal lymphatics. It can also spread from the external ear through a traumatic perforation or via the blood but it is rare.
Solution to Question 2:
Choanal atresia does not predispose to eustachian tube obstruction. Eustachian tube obstruction is caused by:
Extrinsic causes:
Adenoid hypertrophy
Nasopharyngeal tumors
Nasal pack
Intrinsic causes:
Allergic rhinitis
Rhinosinusitis
Upper respiratory tract infection
Defective functioning of the tube:
Cleft palate
Down syndrome
Submucous cleft palate
Eustachian tube obstruction can lead to complications such as:
Acute suppurative otitis media
Otitis media with effusion
Chronic suppurative otitis media
Atelectasis and ossicular necrosis
Solution to Question 3:
The clinical scenario along with the image showing congested tympanic membrane with purulent effusion and absent cone of light is suggestive of acute suppurative otitis media. The most likely organism implicated is Streptococcus pneumoniae.
Organisms causing ASOM in infants and young children:
Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common)
Haemophilus influenzae
Moraxella catarrhalis
Streptococcus pyogenes
Staphylococcus aureus
Pseudomonas aeruginosa
Solution to Question 4:
The clinical picture and image show the stage of pre-suppuration of acute suppurative otitis media
(ASOM).
During this stage, due to prolonged tubal occlusion, pyogenic organisms invade the tympanic cavity. An inflammatory exudate appears in the middle ear and there is congestion of pars tensa.
A leash of blood vessels appears along with the handle of malleus and at the periphery of the tympanic membrane imparting it a cart-wheel appearance. Later, the whole of the tympanic membrane including pars flaccida becomes uniformly red.
Symptoms of this stage include marked earache, a high degree of fever, hearing loss, and tinnitus (seen only in adults). Tuning fork tests show the conductive type of hearing loss.
Solution to Question 5:
Pain is most severe in stage of suppuration in acute suppurative otitis media.
Solution to Question 6:
The most common site of perforation of the tympanic membrane in ASOM is the posterior half of pars tensa where usually, a small perforation is seen.
Note: As per Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat 7th edition, the perforation most commonly occurs in the anteroinferior quadrant. However, as Scott-Brown's Otorhinolaryngology: Head and Neck Surgery; 7th Edition mentions the most common site as the posterior half of pars tensa, we have picked it as the best option in this question.
Solution to Question 7:
Management of ASOM in the pre-suppuration stage involves the usage of antibiotics and decongestants.
Myringotomy is indicated only when there is an impending rupture of tympanic membrane.
Solution to Question 8:
The above clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM) complicated by right-sided LMN facial nerve palsy. Otoscopic finding of bulging tympanic membrane is an indication to perform myringotomy i.e., surgical opening in the tympanic membrane.
Treatment of facial nerve paralysis secondary to otitis media
Conservative management is preferred, using antibiotics and corticosteroids.
Myringotomy and a ventilation tube should be added when spontaneous perforation of the tympanic membrane has not occurred.
Facial nerve decompression is not usually necessary.
Tympanoplasty is the removal of disease from the middle ear and reconstruction of hearing with or without myringoplasty.
Solution to Question 9:
The scenario points towards a diagnosis of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM). Antibiotics form the mainstay of treatment in acute suppurative otitis media, and if the tympanic membrane is bulging, myringotomy should be done.
Myringotomy is the procedure involving incising the tympanic membrane to evacuate pus. It is indicated when:
The tympanic membrane is bulging and there is acute pain.
There is an incomplete resolution despite antibiotics and the drum remains full with persistent conductive deafness.
There is persistent effusion beyond 12 weeks.
Solution to Question 10:
In serous otitis media, a radial incision is made in the anteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane.
A curvilinear incision is used in acute suppurative otitis media in the posteroinferior quadrant
(smiling incision).

Note: Although an anteroinferior incision is the first step, we resort to an anterosuperior incision in the case of thick secretions that are difficult to aspirate. The 'beer-can' principle supports the said mechanism.
Solution to Question 11:
The light-house effect is seen in acute mastoiditis, which is a complication of otitis media. This effect is described as a pulsatile mucopurulent or purulent discharge, coming through a central pin-hole perforation of pars tensa. This suggests a reservoir of infection in the mastoid and middle ear.
Note: Otoscopic signs in intratympanic glomus tumors include:
Red reflex through an intact tympanic membrane
Pulsation sign or Brown sign - when ear canal pressure is raised with Siegel’s speculum, the tumor pulsates vigorously and then blanches
Solution to Question 12:
-hemolytic streptococcus is the most common organism causing acute necrotizing otitis media.
Acute necrotizing otitis media is a variety of acute suppurative otitis media. This is often seen in children suffering from measles, scarlet fever, or influenza.
It leads to the destruction of the entire tympanic membrane, middle ear mucosa, and air cells. There is profuse otorrhoea. In such cases, healing is followed by fibrosis or ingrowth of squamous epithelium from the meatus leading to a secondary acquired cholesteatoma.
Treatment is early antibiotic therapy for at least 7- 10 days. Cortical mastoidectomy may be indicated if medical treatment fails to control or the condition gets complicated by acute mastoiditis.
Solution to Question 13:
Glue ear is also called secretory otitis media. It refers to otitis media with effusion.
Solution to Question 14:
Otitis media with effusion, or glue ear, is the most common cause of hearing loss in children. Clinical features of glue ear include:
Bilateral, painless, and fluctuating hearing loss. Conductive hearing loss not more than 40 dB is bserved.
Defective and delayed development of speech.
Occasional mild earaches are present.
Solution to Question 15:
The effusion is thick, viscid and sterile in most cases of serous otitis media. Etiology of serous otitis media:
Malfunctioning of eustachian tube:
Adenoid hyperplasia in children - causes bilateral serous otitis media
Benign and malignant tumors of the nasopharynx - should always be excluded in unilateral serous otitis media in an adult
Cleft lip, cleft palate and chronic tonsillitis - interference with ET opening
Otitic barotrauma
Allergy - increased middle ear secretions
Unresolved ASOM - due to inadequate treatment dosage or duration
Viral infections - increased secretory activity due to stimulation of middle ear mucosa
Solution to Question 16:
The given clinical scenario and image suggest a diagnosis of serous otitis media.
The golden yellow discoloration of the tympanic membrane is caused by the clear watery
straw-colored effusion filling the middle ear. Since the fluid is clear, one can see the structures of the middle ear quite clearly on otoscopy.
Patients having serous otitis media will have hearing loss that rarely exceeds 40 dB. This deafness can pass unnoticed, and maybe accidentally discovered during audiometric screening tests.
Because of hearing loss, the development of speech is delayed or defective. Otoscopic findings in serous otitis media:
Fluid level and air bubbles are seen when fluid is thin and the tympanic membrane transparent.
In chronic cases, the fluid becomes very sticky. Hence, the name glue ear.
The tympanic membrane is often dull and opaque with a loss of light reflex.
The mobility of the tympanic membrane is restricted.
Solution to Question 17:

Tuberculosis of the ear is usually secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. It occasionally spreads hematogenously, from a tubercular focus in the lungs, tonsils, and cervical or mesenteric lymph nodes
It presents as a painless condition with foul-smelling discharge from the ear, that does not respond to standard antibiotic treatment. Patients have severe hearing loss that is out of proportion to symptoms. Although predominantly conductive, sensorineural hearing loss may also occur if the labyrinth is involved.
A thickened tympanic membrane with multiple perforations in pars tensa of the tympanic membrane and pale granulations in the middle ear cleft is seen.

necrosis. Smears and culture of ear discharge may be positive for acid-fast bacilli (AFB). Evidence of primary pulmonary tuberculosis may also be seen on chest radiography.
Facial nerve palsy is a common complication. Mastoiditis, postauricular fistula, and osteomyelitis are also seen.
Treatment includes aural toilet, treatment of secondary bacterial infections, and a full course of antitubercular therapy followed by reconstructive surgery.
Solution to Question 21:

Tuberculosis of the ear usually occurs secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. It is occasionally blood-borne, spreading from a tubercular focus in the lungs, tonsils, cervical or mesenteric lymph nodes. Tuberculous otitis media is mostly seen in children and young adults.
It presents as a painless condition with foul-smelling discharge from the ear, that does not respond to standard antibiotic treatment. A thickened tympanic membrane with multiple perforations in pars tensa of the tympanic membrane and pale granulations in the middle ear cleft is seen.

Antitubercular therapy
Aural toilet
Treatment of secondary infection
Mastoid surgery for complications.
Reconstructive middle ear surgery is delayed till antitubercular therapy has been completed.

Solution to Question 1:
The middle ear is not lined by keratinizing squamous epithelium, and hence its presence anywhere within the middle ear cleft is considered cholesteatoma.
Various kinds of epithelia lining the middle ear are:
Ciliated columnar- around the eustachian tube opening (Protympanum)

Solution to Question 2:
The image shows the presence of a large mass of white keratin debris in the left upper quadrant of the left tympanic membrane. This along with clinical scenario is suggestive of
cholesteatoma which is also known as epidermosis or keratoma
Cholesteatoma is the presence of stratified squamous epithelium in middle ear where it is not usually present, i.e., skin in wrong place.
A central white mass, consisting of keratin debris is produced by the matrix. For this reason, it has also been named epidermosis or keratoma.
The term cholesteatoma is a misnomer because it neither contains cholesterol crystals nor it is a tumor to merit the suffix “oma.”
Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of secondary acquired cholesteatoma. The history of middle ear infection and hearing loss after surgery of the tympanic membrane makes the diagnosis more likely.
Classification of cholesteatoma:
Congenital cholesteatoma is that which has its nidus of trapped squamous epithelium present at birth.
Primary acquired cholesteatoma presents with no history of previous otitis media or a pre-existing perforation. It is associated with a defect in pars flaccida.
Secondary acquired cholesteatoma presents with a history of previous otitis media or a pre-existing perforation. It is associated with a defect in pars tensa.
Solution to Question 4:
von Békésy proposed the traveling wave theory, whereas Sade’s metaplasia theory explains the origin of cholesteatoma.
Cholesteatoma can be of 2 main types:
Congenital cholesteatoma - explained by the presence of congenital cell rests within the middle ear and other parts of the temporal bone.
Acquired cholesteatoma - explained by a pathology either within the mastoid air cell system and eustachian tube drainage, or the tympanic membrane epithelium.
Solution to Question 5:
The most accepted theory for secondary cholesteatoma is Habermann's theory. It proposes that the skin of the external auditory meatus grows or migrates into the middle ear through the posterosuperior marginal perforation or attic perforation forming cholesteatoma.
Solution to Question 6:
Prussak’s space is the most common site of primary cholesteatoma. It is the space in the epitympanum lying in between pars flaccida and the neck of the malleus.
Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical scenario with the otoendoscopy showing a white pearly mass behind the intact eardrum in the anterosuperior quadrant is suggestive of congenital cholesteatoma. Levenson criteria should be satisfied in order to diagnose this condition.
Levenson criteria:
A white mass behind the normal tympanic membrane
Normal pars tensa and pars flaccida
No prior history of otorrhoea
No prior history of otological procedure
Episodes of otitis media with effusion should not be considered as exclusion criteria.
Another popular guideline used is Derlaki and Clemis which includes all the above except for the 4th criteria.
Solution to Question 8:
Cholesteatoma does not cause bone destruction by pressure necrosis.
Bone destruction by cholesteatoma has been attributed to enzymes liberated by osteoclasts and mononuclear inflammatory cells such as:
Collagenase
Acid phosphatase and
Proteolytic enzymes.
Pediatric cholesteatoma (PC) has more inflammation and greater chances of ossicular erosion compared to adults. However, PC has lesser chances of petrous labyrinth invasion and lateral semicircular canal fistula formation.
Solution to Question 9:
Residual cholesteatoma is most likely to be seen in the sinus tympani.
The involvement of sinus tympani, along with posterior mesotympanum, is a recognized risk factor for residual cholesteatoma. This is because it is particularly difficult to remove the disease from these areas. Canal wall-up procedures have a higher risk of leaving residual disease behind than the canal wall-down procedures.
Sinus tympani or infra pyramidal recess is the medial of the two posterior spaces in the middle ear.
It is bounded by:
Pyramid and vertical segment of facial nerve laterally
The stapes & oval window medially
Ponticulus superiorly
Subiculum inferiorly

Chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) is the single most important cause of hearing impairment in rural populations. Children with CSOM have poor academic performance.

The clinical scenario of intermittent mucoid discharge and central perforation of the tympanic membrane points to a diagnosis of tubotympanic type of CSOM, which is not associated with cholesteatoma. Atticoantral type is associated with cholesteatoma and it leads to dangerous complications due to its bone-eroding properties.
Etiology of tubotympanic (benign or safe) type of CSOM:
As a sequela of acute otitis media
Ascending infection via the eustachian tube
Allergic conditions
Bone destruction is not present in this type.
Culture reveals mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection.
Aural polyp if present should be removed and not avulsed before starting local treatment. This is due to the fact that the polyp may be arising from the stapes, facial nerve, or horizontal canal and its avulsion can lead to facial paralysis or labyrinthitis.
Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tympanosclerosis. It is a sequela of long-standing middle ear disease where there are hyaline deposits within the middle ear, which calcify leading to impaired mobility of ossicles.
The common sites are the tympanic membrane, promontory, ossicles, joints, tendons, and oval and round windows.
When hyalinization and calcification involve only the tympanic membrane, it is known as myringosclerosis.

Features of a permanent perforation:
Seen in chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM)
Is similar to an epithelial lined fistulous tract
Cannot be medically managed, thus mandating surgery

The given scenario describes the round window-shielding effect that is seen in tubotympanic type of CSOM.
The round window-shielding effect is where the ear discharge shields the round window from sound waves. During the inactive phase (no discharge), the sound strikes both the oval window and round window together and the noise cancels itself out. So, the hearing is worse when the ear is dry.
Cholesteatoma hearer is a patient with a discontinuous ossicular chain but the sound is conducted through the cholesteatoma to the footplate. On removing the cholesteatoma by surgery, the patient has worse hearing.
Solution to Question 16:
The patch test is useful in assessing the status of the ossicles preoperatively so that the surgeon can be prepared for ossicular reconstruction if required. It is done in tubotympanic type of CSOM.
A thin paper-like cigarette foil is soaked in vaseline and cut into the size of perforation and is used to close the perforation. Pure tone audiometry is done before and after the closure of perforation. Results are as follows:
Improved hearing – intact ossicular chain
Decreased hearing – ossicular fixity or discontinuity
No improvement – technical fault or improper hearing.
Another test done in the tubotympanic type of CSOM is Bonsin's test. When the eardrum is painted with 1 in 20% solution of silver nitrate, the perforation stands out as a black spot against a white background.
Option A: Nine-step test is used to predict the ears at risk of middle ear barotrauma.
Options B and D: The side-step test and Unterberger test are vestibular tests and are positive in perilymphatic fistula.

Central perforation in the antero-inferior quadrant of tympanic membrane is commonly seen
in tubotympanic type, while marginal perforation in the postero-superior quadrant is commonly seen in atticoantral type of CSOM.
Bloody, scant, foul-smelling ear discharge, ear pain, hearing loss, and tinnitus are often seen in the atticoantral type of CSOM.
Solution to Question 18:
Atticoantral type also called unsafe or dangerous type involves perforation of Shrapnell's membrane or pars flaccida (attic perforation).
The disease is often associated with a bone-eroding process such as cholesteatoma, granulations, or osteitis. The risk of complications is high in this variety.

Option A: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection/pus breaks through the thin medial side of the tip of the mastoid and presents as a swelling in the upper part of the neck.

The clinical scenario of severe pain in his right ear associated with high-grade fever, profuse ear discharge, mastoid tenderness, and perforation of the tympanic membrane is suggestive of acute mastoiditis, which has most likely occurred as a complication of acute infection of the middle ear. If this infection is to burst out through the medial side of the tip of the mastoid, it results in the formation of Bezold abscess.
Acute mastoiditis is used to refer to an acute infection that spreads from the mucosa, lining the mastoid air cells, to involve the bony walls of the mastoid air cell system.
The image below shows a picture of acute mastoiditis:

Blood leukocytes and ESR is raised. CT scan of the temporal bone shows clouding of air cells due to the collection of exudate in them. In later stages, a cavity may be seen in the mastoid.
Treatment is done by administration of intravenous antibiotics and if indicated, surgical procedures such as myringotomy and cortical mastoidectomy.
Abscesses in Relation to mastoid infection are:
Bezold abscess lies deep to the sternocleidomastoid and presents as a swelling in the tip of the mastoid or the angle of the jaw and is seen in the upper part of the posterior triangle or the parapharyngeal space
The images below show a picture of Bezold abscess:


Other abscesses in relation to mastoid infection:
Post auricular abscess - it is the most common abscess that forms over the mastoid. In infants and children, this presents over the MacEwen’s triangle.
Zygomatic abscess - infection of the zygomatic air cells. It is situated at the posterior root of the zygoma
Luc abscess (meatal abscess) - the pus breaks through the bony wall between the mastoid antrum and external auditory meatus

Persistent ear discharge (otitis media)
Solution to Question 17:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral sinus thrombophlebitis. It is an inflammation of the inner wall of the lateral venous sinus with the formation of an intrasinus thrombus.
Clinical features of lateral sinus thrombophlebitis:
Hectic picket fence fever with chills and rigors. This is due to septicemia. The clinical picture resembles malaria but lacks regularity.
Headache - In the early stage, it may be due to peri-sinus abscess and is mild. Later, it may be severe when intracranial pressure rises due to venous obstruction.
Griesinger’s sign - this is due to thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. Edema appears over the posterior part of the mastoid.
Papilloedema - its presence depends on obstruction to venous return. It is often seen with the right sinus (which is larger than the left).
Tenderness along the jugular vein - This is seen when thrombophlebitis extends along the jugular vein. There may be associated enlargement and inflammation of the jugular chain of ymph nodes and torticollis.
Investigations:
Blood culture
CSF analysis - normal except for increased CSF pressure that helps in ruling out meningitis.
X-ray mastoid shows:
Clouding of air cells seen in acute mastoiditis.
Destruction of bone seen in cholesteatoma.
CECT shows a typical delta sign.

Treatment:
Intravenous antibacterial therapy
Mastoidectomy and exposure of sinus
Ligation of internal jugular vein
Anticoagulant therapy

The continuing discharge from the granulation tissue has caused the surface epithelia of the tympanic membrane to become edematous and thickened. This gives the surface of the tympanic membrane a thickened whitish appearance.
The primary aim in surgical treatment is to remove the disease and render the ear safe, and second in priority is to preserve or reconstruct hearing but never at the cost of the primary aim. Mastoidectomy is done.

Solution to Question 1:
Otosclerosis affects the otic capsule.
The otic capsule is the dense bony labyrinth of the inner ear that surrounds the cochlea, the vestibule, and the semicircular canals. In otosclerosis, one or more foci of irregularly laid spongy bone replace part of the normally dense bone.
The inner ear is divided into:
The membranous labyrinth is also called the otic labyrinth. It is filled with endolymph.
The bony labyrinth, which is also called the otic capsule.
Periotic labyrinth, which is the space between the bony and membranous labyrinth and is filled with perilymph.
Solution to Question 2:
Otosclerosis affects the enchondral layer of the otic capsule.
Within the enchondral layer, there are sometimes islands of unossified cartilage rests that later give rise to otosclerosis.
The otic capsule is made of 3 layers:
Endosteal: Innermost
Enchondral: Middle layer derived from cartilage that ossifies
Periosteal: Outermost layer
Solution to Question 3:
The most common site of origin of otosclerosis is the fissula ante fenestram lying in front of the oval window. It is seen in the stapedial type of otosclerosis.
Types of otosclerosis :
Stapedia
Cochlear
Histological.
Stapedial otosclerosis is the most common type of otosclerosis.
Solution to Question 4:
The otosclerotic focus is biscuit type when the disease process involves the entire footplate except for the annular ligament.
The otosclerotic foci in the stapedial type of otosclerosis can be of various types:
Anterior focus - involving only the fissula ante fenestrum
Posterior focus- involving only the fissula post fenestrum
Circumferential - affects the margin of the footplate only (annular ligament alone)
Biscuit type - affects the entire footplate except for the annular ligament
Obliterative- affects the entire footplate & its annular ligament.

Solution to Question 5:
Otosclerosis has an autosomal dominant type of inheritance.
About 50% of the cases of otosclerosis have a positive family history while the rest are sporadic. Genetic studies reveal that it is an autosomal dominant trait with incomplete penetrance and variable expressivity.
Solution to Question 6:
The most common age group when the hearing loss in otosclerosis usually manifests is 20-30 years of age. It is rare before 10 and after 40 years.
Solution to Question 7:
HRCT shows the double-ring sign in cochlear otosclerosis, not in the stapedial type.
Otosclerosis affects females twice as often as males. But in India, otosclerosis seems to predominate in males.
Stapedotomy is contraindicated in children because recurrent eustachian tube dysfunction is common in them. This can displace the prosthesis or cause acute otitis media.
Measles RNA has been found in otosclerotic foci implicating its possible role in pathogenesis.
Solution to Question 8:

The following hearing defects are seen in otosclerosis:
Painless progressive bilateral conductive hearing loss most commonly.
Sensorineural hearing loss may be seen in cochlear type of otosclerosis.
Paracusis willisii: Patient hears better in noisy surroundings as other people raise their voice to be heard.

Option B - Blue dot sign is seen in the torsion of the testicular appendage. Blue cement sign and islets in ocean sign do not exist.

The tympanic membrane has a normal appearance in most cases. This is indicative of a matured or inactive focus of otosclerotic bone.

Option D - In the case of otitis media with effusion the tympanic membrane is often dull and opaque with loss of light reflex.

Option C: Setting sun sign is an eye sign seen in hydrocephalus.

Solution to Question 12:
Gelle’s is a tuning fork test done to clinically confirm otosclerosis in the olden days.
It is based on the fact that in a normal ear if pressure is increased in the external ear the stapes footplate will get medialized and will stop conducting sound. But, in an ear with otosclerosis of the footplate, there will be no movements and the patient will continue to hear the sound. Thus, Gelle’s test is considered positive in normal persons and in those with sensorineural hearing loss. It is negative when the ossicular chain is fixed or disconnected.
Stenger’s test is done to rule out malingering.
Schwabach is a tuning fork test that compares the bone conduction of the patient with that of the examiner.
Rinne’s is a tuning fork test that compares bone conduction with air conduction.

Air conduction is poor & worse for lower frequencies.
Bone conduction is normal.
There is a large air-bone gap
In some cases, there is a dip in the bone conduction curve. It is different at different frequencies but the maximum dip is at 2000 Hz and is called Carhart’s notch.

Note: Boiler’s notch is a similar dip in BC and AC curve but at 4000 Hz seen in noise-induced hearing loss.

Solution to Question 17:
Sodium fluoride is used in the medical management of otosclerosis. This is an active case of otosclerosis evidenced by Schwartze’s sign and in an active case of otosclerosis medical management is preferred.
Surgery is contraindicated if Schwartze’s sign is positive.
Schwartze sign - A reddish hue is seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane. This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity.
In an active case of otosclerosis, medical management with Sodium fluoride (NaF) is preferred because NaF hastens the maturity of active focus in otosclerosis. It acts by inhibiting the osteoclasts and decreasing the proteolytic enzymes.
Solution to Question 18:
The above clinical scenario of bilateral progressive conductive deafness with As type of tympanogram and absent acoustic reflexes is suggestive of otosclerosis. Gentamicin is not used in the management of otosclerosis.
Medical management includes the use of sodium fluoride and bisphosphonates in active cases.
Surgical management includes stapedectomy and stapedotomy, though the latter is preferred due to decreased risk of fistula formation.
Hearing aids may be used as an alternative to surgery.
Solution to Question 19:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of otosclerosis and the treatment of choice for otosclerosis is stapedotomy.
Stapedotomy is the excision of the superstructure of stapes and drilling a hole in the footplate
& placing a piston in the hole. This is the treatment of choice.
Stapedectomy is the excision of the entire stapes (superstructure + footplate) and placing a piston in its place. It is outdated.
NaF is used in an active case of otosclerosis to hasten maturation. Note:
Both stapedectomy and stapedotomy have been described for the treatment of otosclerosis. Even in the stapedectomy procedure, stapedotomy (drilling) has been practiced. Hence stapedotomy is preferred over stapedectomy and is considered the treatment of choice.
In the above case since Rinne’s test is negative on both ears, it indicates bilateral conductive deafness. Weber’s test will lateralize to the ear with greater conductive loss.

The piston is placed between the incus and oval window.
Stapedotomy is done to bypass the immobile stapes using a piston which will take over the function of conducting sound. For this reason, the piston replaces the removed stapes superstructure.

Young children
Professional athletes, pilots, construction workers, and divers: Sudden changes in pressure can displace the piston and cause vertigo.
Those who work in noisy surroundings: Surgery makes them more vulnerable to noise-induced hearing loss.

Immediate on-table improvement of hearing can be assessed
Damage to the inner ear can be assessed by the patient’s symptoms of vertigo/ nystagmus
Damage to the facial nerve can be checked.

Cholesteatoma is not a complication of stapedotomy. Complications of stapedotomy:

Lempert’s fenestration, an alternative window is created in the lateral semicircular canal to function for the obliterated oval window.
Lempert’s fenestration operation for otosclerosis is outdated now. It has the disadvantage of a postoperative mastoid cavity and an inherent hearing loss of 25 dB which cannot be corrected.

Solution to Question 1:
Ménière’s disease is also called endolymphatic hydrops.
It is a disorder of the inner ear where the endolymphatic system is distended with endolymph. This occurs due either due to excessive production or faulty absorption of endolymph.
It has 2 variants:
Cochlear hydrops - the main feature is hearing loss. Vertigo is absent.
Vestibular hydrops - repeated episodes of vertigo without loss of hearing.
Solution to Question 2:
Ménière’s disease is commonly seen in the age group of 35-60 years and incidence peaks in the fifth decade. It is a disorder of the inner ear causing a sensorineural type of hearing loss. Usually, it is unilateral but the other ear may be affected after a few years.
Symptoms of the disease occur in attacks (episodes) and there is not a constant presence of the symptoms.
Solution to Question 3:
Otalgia is least likely to be present in a patient diagnosed with Ménière’s disease. The characteristic triad of Ménière’s disease includes:
Episodic vertigo- attacks come in clusters, with periods of spontaneous remission lasting for weeks, months, or years
Fluctuating hearing loss- hearing is affected during episodes of vertigo, improves after the attack, and maybe normal during remissions
Tinnitus- low-pitched whistling or roaring type
Warning symptoms preceding an attack of vertigo in Ménière’s:
Sense of fullness in the ear
Change in pitch or increasing intensity of tinnitus
Decrease in hearing
Solution to Question 4:
Intolerance to loud sounds in this patient is due to the recruitment phenomenon (sound is amplified to be heard better). It is a feature of all cochlear pathologies.
The characteristic presentation of a middle-aged man with vertigo, tinnitus, and intolerance to loud sounds points to a diagnosis of Ménière’s disease. It is a cochlear pathology, hence shows the recruitment phenomenon.
The rollover phenomenon is a feature of retro-cochlear pathologies like an acoustic neuroma. Diplacusis is the perception of a single auditory stimulus as sounds of a different pitch in two ears. Tullio phenomenon is a condition where loud sounds precipitate a vertiginous attack.
Solution to Question 5:
The phenomenon described above is the Tullio phenomenon and is not seen in ASOM with a perforated tympanic membrane.
The Tullio phenomenon refers to sound-induced vertigo. People with this condition experience unsteadiness, vertigo, nausea and rapid involuntary eye movements (nystagmus) when exposed to
loud sounds or noise. It is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate. Some cases of Ménière’s disease show the Tullio phenomenon.
It is also seen whenever there is a third mobile window lesion such as otic syphilis, perilymph fistula and dehiscence of semicircular canals.
Solution to Question 6:
Early Ménière’s disease affects lower frequencies. As the disease progresses, all the frequencies become affected.
There is no classical audiogram pattern that can be used to identify Ménière’s disease. However, there are certain features that have been commonly observed. These include:
A varying degree of sensorineural hearing loss.
This hearing loss is usually low frequency.

Solution to Question 7:
Summating potential: action potential ratio (SP: AP) >0.4 or 0.5 are consistent with a diagnosis of Ménière’s disease.
Normally, the ratio of SP to AP is 0.3 (suggestive of normal cochlear function).
Solution to Question 8:
The given clinical history points to a diagnosis of Ménière’s disease. The glycerol test is useful for the diagnosis of Ménière’s disease.
Glycerol is an osmotic diuretic which when given orally reduces hydrops and improves symptoms. Electrocochleography done along with a glycerol test. An improvement after administration of glycerol is diagnostic of Ménière’s disease.
The caloric test used in Ménière’s disease is not diagnostic as it is abnormal in many other conditions like ototoxicity, vestibular schwannoma, vestibular neuritis, etc.
Dix-Hallpike test is performed to diagnose BPPV. A positive test would result in a vertiginous episode and nystagmus observed by the clinician.
Solution to Question 9:
The most likely diagnosis would be Lermoyez syndrome.
It is a variant of Ménière’s wherein the symptoms appear in reverse order. The patient presents with a progressive hearing loss followed by an attack of vertigo which causes improvement in hearing.
Lemierre’s syndrome is a condition characterized by infectious thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein and bacteremia caused by primarily anaerobic organisms, following a recent oropharyngeal infection.
Leriche syndrome, commonly referred to as an aortoiliac occlusive disease, is due to thrombotic occlusion of the abdominal aorta just above the site of its bifurcation.
Leigh syndrome (subacute necrotizing encephalomyelopathy) is a rare genetic neurometabolic disorder characterized by degeneration of the CNS.
Solution to Question 10:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis.
Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis (drop attacks) is when a patient with Meniere’s develops sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness. It is an uncommon manifestation. Its pathogenesis is not well understood.
Tullio phenomenon: It is a condition seen with some cases of Meniere's disease, where loud sounds or noise produce vertigo. This phenomenon is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.
Lermoyez syndrome: Here symptoms of Meniere's disease are seen in reverse order. Initially, there is a progressive deterioration of hearing, followed by an attack of vertigo.
Solution to Question 11:
CSOM is a middle ear disease with symptoms of ear discharge and is not a differential for Ménière’s.
Ménière’s is a cochlear pathology with symptoms of vertigo, hearing loss & tinnitus. Differentials of Ménière’s disease:
Vestibular neuronitis
BPPV
Cervical spondylosis

Solution to Question 18:
The definitive treatment of intractable vertigo due to Ménière’s disease is labyrinthectomy.
Labyrinthectomy involves uniform destruction of hearing and vestibular function. Ideal candidates have no functional hearing and have failed more conservative treatments, such as gentamicin injection. Despite this morbidity, labyrinthectomy has the highest rate of vertigo control (>95%), more than vestibular neurectomy (78-90%), and is considered the single definitive treatment.
The step-by-step management approach for Ménière's disease consists of dietary modifications and vestibular suppressants as the initial measures, followed by intratympanic gentamicin ablation, and finally, surgical intervention.
Primarily, the management of Menier's disease involves a sodium restricted diet and diuretics like acetazolamide (Option A). They are more useful for short-term control.
Gentamicin (Option D) is a selective vestibulotoxic aminoglycoside antibiotic that is preferentially taken up by type I hair cells. It is opted for only if dietary modifications and vestibular suppressants have failed to control the symptoms. If used judiciously, hearing is preserved.
The options for surgical management include - Endolymphatic sac surgery, vestibular neurectomy, and labyrinthectomy. Endolymphatic sac surgery is currently declining in popularity due to lack of evidence of vertigo control.
Vestibular neurectomy (Option C) refers to selective ablation of the vestibular nerve. Even though it is considered a hearing sparing surgery and carries comparable rates of vertigo control as labyrinthectomy, it is an intradural procedure and carries a greater risk of complications. Hearing loss will still progress as it would have in the natural course of illness.
Solution to Question 19:
Sensorineural hearing loss is not seen in superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome
(SSCDS). They may experience mild to moderate hearing conductive loss.
Conductive hearing loss is due to the abnormal transmission and dissipation of acoustic energy through the defect (third window), leading to reduced conduction to the cochlea for lower frequencies. This can manifest as a low-frequency air-bone gap at multiple frequencies. There is no defect in the cochlea or the auditory pathway.
Superior semicircular canal dehiscence (SSCD) is a condition in which bone between the apex of the superior semicircular canal and the middle cranial fossa is absent. This causes endolymph in the labyrinthine system to move with sound or pressure, causing an activation of the vestibular system.
Patients may have vestibular symptoms like vertigo triggered by loud sounds (Tullio phenomenon)or pressure such as coughing and can also experience hyperacusis for
bone-conducted sounds. They may perceive the sounds of their own eye movements or footsteps in the affected ear.
The patients may exhibit nystagmus when exposed to loud sounds or during the Valsalva maneuver or pressure in the ear canal (positive fistula test). The direction of the nystagmus aligns with the affected superior semicircular canal, and some patients may tilt their heads in the plane of the affected superior semicircular canal in response to loud sounds.
Noncontrast HRCT of the temporal bone can demonstrate the defect. The click-evoked VEMP (vestibular evoked myogenic potential) response and vestibuloocular reflex are pronounced in SSCD patients, in which the evoked eye movements align with the affected superior canal.
For mild symptoms, avoidance of triggers is recommended. In case of severe disabling symptoms, surgical resurfacing of the superior semicircular canal or plugging of the superior semicircular canal may be attempted.
Solution to Question 20:
The given clinical scenario, with complaints of dizziness associated with postural change and no history of loss of consciousness is suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).
BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal.
A positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis of BPPV. In this maneuver, the patient begins sitting up with their head turned 45 degrees toward the ear to be tested. Then the patient is
made to lie down quickly with their head past the end of the bed. Then, the patient's neck is extended 20 degrees below the horizontal. The clinician then watches the patient's eyes for torsional and up-beating nystagmus, which should persist for no more than one minute. This would indicate a positive test.
Epley's maneuver is performed to reposition the crystals into the macula from the semicircular canals. This is only a temporary cure and there is a high rate of recurrence.

A patient presenting with vertigo should be evaluated for ruling out the central lesions (like a tumor in the fourth ventricle, multiple sclerosis, etc) before confirming the diagnosis of BPPV. Dix-Hallpike maneuver helps rule out central lesions and also diagnose BPPV.
Dix-Hallpike maneuver:
The maneuver starts with the patient in a sitting position.
Their head is turned 45 degrees towards the ear to be tested.
The examiner quickly brings the patient to a supine position with their head 30 degrees below the horizontal.
The 45-degree head rotation is maintained during the procedure.
Now the examiner observes the patient for nystagmus.

Solution to Question 1:
The facial nerve is a mixed cranial nerve which contains both sensory and motor part. It is the 7th cranial nerve.
Solution to Question 2:
The general somatic efferent is not a component of the facial nerve.
Components of the facial nerve:
Special visceral efferent - motor to muscles of facial expression (derived from branchial arches, hence special visceral and not general somatic like the other muscles)
General visceral efferent - secretomotor to lacrimal and submandibular glands
Special visceral afferent - taste from anterior 2/3rd tongue
General somatic afferent - general sensations from pinna, external auditory canal, and tympanic membrane.

Solution to Question 3:
The sensory division of the facial nerve is also called the nerve of Wrisberg. The facial nerve is a mixed nerve having the motor and a sensory root.
Hitzelberger sign refers to hypoesthesia of the posterior meatal wall in acoustic neuroma due to the compression of the facial nerve.
Option A: Jacobson’s nerve - the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (9th cranial nerve). It is associated with glomus tympanicum.
Option B: Arnold’s nerve - the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (10th cranial nerve).
Option D: Herring’s nerve - the carotid sinus branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (9th cranial nerve).

Solution to Question 4:
The taste sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by the special visceral afferent of the facial nerve via chorda tympani nerve.
The taste sensation from the hard and soft palate is also carried by the facial nerve via the greater superficial petrosal nerve to the nucleus tractus solitarius.
Solution to Question 5:
The given image shows left-sided lower motor neuron facial nerve palsy and the motor nucleus is located in the pons. It is located along with abducens and vestibulocochlear nerve nuclei.
Solution to Question 6:
The facial nerve in the pons hooks around the 6th (abducens) nerve nucleus.
It exits the pons ventrally at the pontomedullary (ponto-olivary) junction. It then runs in the cerebellopontine angle to reach the internal auditory meatus.

Solution to Question 7:
The 1st genu of the facial nerve lies on the medial wall of the middle ear and not posterior wall.
It is formed at the geniculate ganglion when the facial nerve from the fundus of the internal acoustic meatus takes a turn posteriorly. Then the facial nerve continues as a tympanic or horizontal segment.
It homes the geniculate ganglion which supplies the lacrimal gland (via greater superficial petrosal nerve). It gives off the first branch of the facial nerve.

Solution to Question 8:
The 2nd genu of the facial nerve lies at the junction of the 3rd and the 4th intratemporal segments, between the tympanic and the mastoid segments.
The 2nd genu of the facial nerve is formed where the horizontal facial nerve takes a turn inferiorly at the junction between the medial and posterior walls of the middle ear.
It continues as the vertical segment of the facial nerve behind the posterior wall of the middle ear. It does not contain a ganglion and does not give any branches.
The course of the facial nerve has 3 parts-
Intracranial
Intratemporal
Extracranial.
Intratemporal part of the facial nerve has 4 segments-
Meatal
Labyrinthine
Tympanic/horizontal
Mastoid/vertical segments.
Option A: Gasserian ganglion is present in the trigeminal nerve.
Option B: The temporal segment of the facial nerve ends with the 2nd genu. The nerve then passes vertically downward to form the mastoid segment. The 2nd branch of facial nerve (nerve to stapedius) arises from this segment close to the level of 2nd genu and not from the 2nd genu.

Solution to Question 9:
The shortest and narrowest segment of the facial nerve is the labyrinthine segment (length 4.0 mm, diameter 0.61–0.68 mm).
The labyrinthine segment is from the fundus of meatus to the geniculate ganglion where the nerve takes a turn posteriorly forming a genu. The nerve in the labyrinthine segment has the narrowest diameter and the bony canal in this segment is also the narrowest. Thus edema or inflammation can easily compress the nerve and cause paralysis.

Solution to Question 10:
Involvement of the greater superficial petrosal nerve causes a decrease in lacrimation, detected by the Schirmer test.
It is the first branch of the facial nerve and arises from the geniculate ganglion. It carries secretomotor fibres to the lacrimal gland and the glands of nasal mucosa and palate.

Solution to Question 11:
The injury to chorda tympani nerve produces loss of taste sensation in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue and it arises from the mastoid or vertical segment of the facial nerve.
Chorda tympani nerve carries the taste sensation from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue. It is a branch of the facial nerve arising from the mastoid/vertical segment after the nerve to stapedius before exiting the stylomastoid foramen. It relays in the nucleus of tractus solitarius.

Solution to Question 12:
The congenital dehiscence (absence of bony cover) of the fallopian canal of the facial nerve occurs most commonly in the tympanic or horizontal segment over the oval window.
It is the most common anomaly of the facial canal. A dehiscent nerve is prone to injury at the time of surgery. It gets easily compressed or inflamed in mastoid and middle ear infections.
Solution to Question 13:
The frontal branch is not a terminal branch of the facial nerve. The five terminal branches of the facial nerve are:
Temporal
Zygomatic
Buccal
Mandibular
Cervical
The extratemporal course of the facial nerve starts at the stylomastoid foramen where it exits the temporal bone and runs anteriorly to enter the substance of the parotid gland.
Here it divides into 2 main terminal trunks, the temporofacial and the cervicofacial. These further divide and re-anastomose to give the five terminal branches.

Solution to Question 14:
Anterior belly of digastric is not paralyzed in facial nerve palsy. Muscles supplied by facial nerve:
Nerve to stapedius - stapedius muscle.
Posterior auricular nerve - muscles of the pinna and the occipital belly of occipitofrontalis.
Muscular branches - stylohyoid and posterior belly of digastric.
Terminal branches - muscles of facial expression.
Solution to Question 15:
Facial artery does not supply the facial nerve Vascular Supply of facial nerve:
Anterior-inferior cerebellar artery supplies the nerve in the cerebellopontine angle
Labyrinthine artery, a branch of the anterior-inferior cerebellar artery supplies the nerve in the internal auditory canal
Superficial petrosal artery, a branch of the middle meningeal artery supplies geniculate ganglion and the adjacent region
Stylomastoid artery, a branch of the posterior auricular artery supplies the mastoid segment.
Solution to Question 16:
Posterior semicircular canal is not used as a surgical landmark to identify the facial nerve. Surgical Landmarks of the facial nerve for middle ear and mastoid surgery:
Processus cochleariformis - It demarcates the geniculate ganglion which lies just anterior to it. The tympanic segment of the nerve starts at this level.
Oval window and horizontal semicircular canal - The horizontal segment of the facial nerve runs above the oval window (stapes) and below the horizontal/lateral semicircular canal.
Short process of incus - The vertical segment of the facial nerve lies medial to the short process of incus at the level of aditus.
Pyramid - The vertical segment of the facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and the posterior tympanic sulcus.

Solution to Question 17:
Tragus is used as a surgical landmark to identify facial nerve in parotid surgery. Surgical landmarks of the facial nerve for parotid surgery:
Tragal pointer - triangular inferior portion of the tragus. The main trunk lies 1 cm deep to it.
Tympanomastoid suture - the main trunk lies 6-8 mm deep to it.
Styloid process - the nerve lies lateral to it
Posterior belly of digastric attachment at the digastric groove - the nerve can be found emerging rom the stylomastoid foramen under the muscle but lateral to the styloid process.

Solution to Question 18:
A larger burr is used to prevent facial nerve injury in the mastoid exploration and not a smaller burr.
Measures to reduce facial nerve injury during mastoid exploration:
Good anatomical knowledge
Working parallel to the nerve, never at an angle.
Use the biggest burr available. Smaller burrs are more harmful.
Constant irrigation prevents thermal injury
Granulations present over the facial nerve are best left alone.
Good magnification.
