Solution to Question 1:
The most common type of nerve injury, in general, is neuropraxia. It is also true for facial nerve injury.
Solution to Question 2:
Right upper motor neuron (UMN) facial nerve palsy causes paralysis of lower facial muscles on the left side.
The upper part of the facial nerve’s motor nucleus, which innervates forehead muscles, receives fibers from both the cerebral hemispheres. The lower part of the nucleus, which supplies the lower face, only receives crossed fibers from the contralateral hemisphere. Therefore, the upper part of the face gets bilateral innervation and the lower part of the face gets crossed innervation from the opposite side.
Hence, in supranuclear lesion (UMN palsy), forehead is spared and muscles of the lower half of the opposite side of the face are affected.
In LMN palsy, all muscles of the same side are affected.

Solution to Question 3:
The fibres from the thalamus are responsible for the involuntary movements of facial muscles in emotional states. These fibres reach the facial nerve nucleus via alternate pathways and are unaffected by UMN causes.

Solution to Question 4:
Bell’s palsy is the most common cause of LMN facial nerve palsy. It is defined as idiopathic, ipsilateral lower motor neuron (LMN) facial paralysis, or paresis of acute onset.

Solution to Question 5:
Bell’s palsy affects both males and females equally. It is an acute onset idiopathic ipsilateral LMN facial nerve palsy.
Most of the evidence supports the viral etiology due to herpes simplex, herpes zoster, or the Epstein–Barr virus.
Positive family history is present in 6–8% of patients. Most of the patients recover fully and the remaining require surgery. Recurrent facial palsy is seen in 3–10% of cases.
Solution to Question 6:
In Bell’s phenomenon, the eyeball turns upwards and outwards on the affected side while attempting to close the eyes.
This phenomenon is seen in LMN facial palsy. The following image shows Bell's phenomenon.

Solution to Question 7:
Ptosis is not seen in patients with Bell’s palsy. Clinical presentation of Bell’s palsy:
Sudden onset
Bell's phenomenon
Asymmetrical face
Some may complain of noise intolerance (stapedial paralysis) or loss of taste (involvement of chorda tympani).
The following image shows a patient with Bell's palsy.

Solution to Question 8:
Noise intolerance in a patient with facial nerve palsy is due to stapedius muscle paralysis.
The stapedius muscle is supplied by the facial nerve via nerve to stapedius. It acts by dampening the loud sounds and the loss of this function results in hyperacusis.
Tensor veli palatini helps in opening the eustachian tube, hence also called dilator tubae muscle.
Tensor tympani, supplied by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve, also helps in dampening the loud sounds. It is not involved in facial nerve palsy.
Solution to Question 9:
Electroneuronography is most useful when done between 4 and 21 days of the onset of complete paralysis.
Degeneration of the nerve fibers cannot be detected earlier than 48–72 h of its commencement. Hence electrodiagnostic tests are done after 72 hours following injury.
Solution to Question 10:
Electromyography is not a topodiagnostic test used in facial palsy. It is used to monitor nerve degeneration in facial palsy.
Topodiagnostic tests are done to identify the site of lesion in the intratemporal part of the facial nerve. They are:
Schirmer test - quantification of lacrimation
Stapedial reflex
Taste test by electrogustometry
Submandibular salivary flow test.
Solution to Question 11:
Injury at the level or proximal to the geniculate ganglion will produce dry eye due to decreased lacrimation.
Geniculate ganglion gives the secretomotor fibers to the lacrimal gland via the greater superficial petrosal nerve.
Solution to Question 12:
The site of lesion in this patient with loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of tongue and absent acoustic reflex is at the tympanic segment.
Injury to the greater superficial petrosal nerve leads to loss of lacrimation which is detected by the Schirmer test. It is the first branch given at the level of the geniculate ganglion.
Injury to the nerve to stapedius, the first motor branch of the facial nerve, leads to loss of stapedial reflex and hyperacusis, which can be detected by tympanometry.
Injury to chorda tympani nerve leads to loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue which is detected by electrogustometry and reduced submandibular and sublingual salivary flow detected by salivary flow test.
So in this patient, the lesion is proximal to the origin of nerve to stapedius i.e. tympanic segment, and not proximal to geniculate ganglion as the lacrimation is normal.
Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Bell's palsy and statements 2,4 and 5 are false with respect to the treatment.
Management of Bell's palsy:
Steroids are the drug of choice for Bell's palsy. If the patient reports within 1 week, the adult dose of prednisolone 1 mg/kg/day in 2 divided doses for 5 days should be given.
Steroids can be combined with acyclovir for herpes zoster oticus or if viral etiology is suspected in Bell's palsy.
General measures include reassurance, physiotherapy, or massage of facial muscles, and care of the eye to prevent exposure keratitis. It includes artificial tears drops, eye ointment, and taping of eyes during the night. If the recovery is prolonged, temporary tarsorrhaphy is indicated.
Surgical treatments like nerve decompression are done only when the medical management fails.
Solution to Question 14:
Cleft palate is not seen in a patient with Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome. Melkersson-Rosenthal Syndrome is an idiopathic disorder consisting of a triad of:
Facial paralysis
Swelling of lips and
Fissured tongue.
The following image shows a patient with Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome.

Solution to Question 15:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ramsay-Hunt syndrome and it is caused by the Herpes zoster virus.
The image shows right-sided LMN facial paralysis along with vesicular rash in the external auditory canal and pinna which is a classical presentation of this syndrome.
Solution to Question 16:
The given clinical scenario with facial nerve palsy and vesicles in the external auditory canal is suggestive of Ramsay-Hunt syndrome (Herpes Zoster oticus). Surgery is not the mainstay of treatment. Steroids and antivirals are the mainstays of treatment.
There may also be anesthesia of the face, giddiness, and hearing impairment due to the involvement of the 5th and 8th cranial nerves.
Solution to Question 17:
The given clinical scenario is crocodile tear syndrome or Bogard syndrome (gustatory lacrimation) and is due to faulty regeneration of facial nerve fibres. It presents as unilateral lacrimation during eating and drinking.
It is seen in cases where the facial nerve is damaged proximal to the geniculate ganglion. During regeneration, the fibres supplying the salivary gland aberrantly supply the lacrimal gland.
It can be treated by section of the greater superficial petrosal nerve.
Solution to Question 18:
The given clinical scenario is Frey’s syndrome or gustatory sweating. It is due to aberrant reinnervation (or cross innervation) of parasympathetic fibers of the auriculotemporal nerve (which supplies parotid) with sympathetic sweat glands.
The patient usually presents with sweating and flushing over the parotid area during mastication. This usually occurs after parotid surgery.
It is diagnosed by Minor's test or starch iodine test. The affected area is painted with iodine and is allowed to dry. Then dry corn starch is applied. The starch turns blue on exposure to iodine in the presence of sweat.
Solution to Question 19:
A vascular loop abutting the facial nerve at the cerebellopontine angle is the most common cause of hemifacial spasm. This usually presents as a unilateral involuntary uncontrollable twitching of the face.
Treatment is microvascular decompression or removal of any other inciting cause like acoustic neuroma, congenital cholesteatoma, glomus tumor. In refractory cases, botulinum toxin and selective nerve sectioning are done.
Solution to Question 20:
The transverse fracture of the petrous temporal bone is most commonly associated with facial nerve palsy.

Solution to Question 21:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of CSF otorrhea and it is seen in longitudinal fracture of the petrous part of the temporal bone.
The transverse fracture of petrous temporal bone and fracture of cribriform plate leads to CSF rhinorrhea.


Solution to Question 22:
HRCT (High-resolution CT) is the investigation of choice for the temporal bone fractures complicated by facial nerve palsy or CSF leak.

Solution to Question 23:
The mandibular nerve cannot be used as a graft for facial nerve surgeries.
Only those nerves whose functions can be sacrificed are chosen as grafts and these are usually sensory nerves.
The most commonly used grafts for facial nerve are:
Greater auricular nerve (can be extracted from the same incision)
Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh
Sural nerve (when a large segment is required).

The length of the eustachian tube is 36 mm (Bony part: 12 mm and Cartilaginous part: 24 mm). It is directed forward, downward, and medially with an angle of 45° to the horizontal axis.
Note: The eustachian tube in infants is 18 mm, i.e. about half the size of an adult eustachian tube.

Solution to Question 2:
The eustachian tube also called the auditory or pharyngotympanic tube connects the nasopharynx with the tympanic cavity.
It is 36 mm long in adults and is divided into two parts:
Bony part - forms the outer one-third of the tube as it is located near the middle ear and is 12 mm in size.
Fibrocartilaginous part - forms the inner two-third as it is located near the nasopharynx and is 24 mm in size.
In the middle ear it opens in the anterior wall and in the nasopharynx it opens 1-1.25 cm posterior to the posterior end of the inferior turbinate.

Solution to Question 3:

Infundibulum is not a part of eustachian tube.

Solution to Question 4:
Tensor veli palatini helps in opening the Eustachian tube during the Valsalva manoeuvre. It is closed at rest and opens intermittently during swallowing, yawning and sneezing.
Opening of the tube
The medial fibres of the tensor veli palatini are attached to the lateral lamina of the tube and contract to open the tubal lumen. It is also called the dilator tubae muscle.
Accessory muscles for opening are levator veli palatine & salpingopharyngeus Closure of the tube
It is mainly due to the elastic recoil of the cartilage aided by the high degree of elastin on the roof.
Ostmann’s pad of fat helps to keep the tube closed.

Solution to Question 5:

Solution to Question 6:
The Eustachian tube in children is wider, shorter (13-18mm), and more horizontal. The cartilaginous part is flaccid due to less elastin.
The above differences make children more prone to retrograde reflux of nasopharyngeal secretions and middle ear infections. In infants along with the secretions, the milk also refluxes back while feeding in the supine position.
Solution to Question 7:
Cleft palate is a cause for functional Eustachian tube (ET) obstruction.
Eustachian tube obstruction can be mechanical, functional or both. Mechanical obstruction can result from intrinsic causes such as inflammation or allergy or extrinsic causes such as tumour or adenoids. Functional obstruction is caused by collapse of the tube due to increased cartilage compliance or failure of active tubal opening mechanism due to poor function of tensor veli palatini.

The procedure depicted in the image is Eustachian tube (ET) catheterization and it uses Politzer’s bag and an ET catheter.
The catheter is passed along the nasal floor and manoeuvred into the ET opening and the bag is insufflated. The outward movement of the tympanic membrane is then noted with an otoscope.
It is an unsafe and outdated ET function test. It can lead to complications like TM rupture, scarring of ET, epistaxis, spread of nasal/pharyngeal infection to the middle ear.
In the methylene blue dye test, the dye is instilled into the middle ear and the time taken by it to stain the pharynx is noted.
Politzer test is a non-invasive alternative for this and works on the same principle. It uses a nasal olive instead of a catheter and is useful in children who can’t perform the Valsalva or Toynbee test.

Treatment includes weight gain, administration of potassium iodide solution. In long-standing cases, specific treatment could include cauterization of tubes or insertion of the grommet.

Severe earache, deafness, and tinnitus are common complaints.

Solution to Question 6:
Movements of the tympanic membrane are more at the periphery than at the center, where the malleus handle is attached. This is called the curved membrane effect and it contributes to the impedance matching mechanism of the ear.
Other factors responsible for the impedance matching mechanism of the middle ear are:
The lever action of the ossicles- handle of malleus is 1.3 times longer than the long process of incus, providing a mechanical advantage of 1.3.
Hydraulic action of the tympanic membrane- relatively large area of the tympanic membrane compared to the stapes footplate.
The medial side of the tympanic membrane is multiphasic whereas the lateral side is uniphasic. This provides a multiple integrated multilever mechanical advantage.
Solution to Question 7:
The traveling wave theory was proposed by von Békésy.
It states that a sound wave, depending on its frequency, reaches maximum amplitude on a particular place on the basilar membrane and stimulates that segment.
Higher frequencies are represented in the basal turn of the cochlea and the progressively lower ones towards the apex.

Rinne’s test is a tuning fork test performed commonly with tuning forks of frequencies such as 128, 256, 512, and 1024 Hz.
Rinne’s test is done by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the patient’s mastoid and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the external auditory meatus (EAC). If he still hears the sound, air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC) i.e. AC>BC. The inferences are as follows:
Rinne's test is considered positive (normal) when the air conduction AC>BC is seen in norma people and people with sensorineural deafness.
It is considered negative when the BC>AC, and is seen in patients with conductive deafness.

But, in an ear with otosclerosis of the footplate, there will be no movements and the patient will continue to hear the sound (negative Gelle's test).
It was once a popular test to find out stapes fixation in otosclerosis but has now been superseded by tympanometry.

Solution to Question 21:
Noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL) damages the outer hair cells, starting in the basal turn of the cochlea. Outer hair cells are affected before the inner hair cells.
NIHL occurs after chronic exposure to less intense sounds. The damage caused by noise trauma depends on the frequency of noise (frequency of 2000 to 3000 Hz causes more damage) intensity, duration of the noise, and preexisting ear disease.
The audiogram in noise-induced hearing loss shows a typical notch at 4000Hz both for air and bone conduction known as acoustic dip/boiler's notch. Patients at this stage complain of
high-pitched tinnitus and difficulty hearing in noisy surroundings. Pre-employment and annual audiograms for persons working at places where noise is above 85 dB (A) help in the early
detection of NIHL.
The human ear can hear frequencies from about 20 to 20,000 Hz. Below 20 Hz, the vibrations are infra-audible, and above 20,000 Hz, they are ultra-sonic. Pure tone audiometry can detect only up to 8000 Hz.
Extended high-frequency audiometry is recommended for early detection of hearing loss, as it can identify hearing impairments before the frequencies necessary for speech comprehension are affected. Distortion product otoacoustic emissions is a more sensitive tool than conventional audiometry, particularly in children under 5 years old for early detection of hearing loss.
A noise of ˜0 dB(A) SPL (acceptable noise levels, sound pressure level), 8 hours a day for 5 days per week is the maximum safe limit as recommended by the Ministry of Labour. As per WHO, 85 dB(A) is considered the highest safe exposure level up to a maximum of 8 hours.
The silence zone extends to a distance of 100 meters around the premises of hospitals, nursing homes, educational institutions, and courts.

Noise levels are measured in dB(A), which prioritizes middle-range frequencies for assessing noise-induced hearing loss while giving less weightage to low and high frequencies.

Solution to Question 4:
The clinical scenario describes a patient with post-pregnancy hearing loss. The audiogram shows conductive deafness along with Carhart's notch (dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz). These findings are highly suggestive of otosclerosis.
Ototoxicity, Meniere’s disease, and noise-induced hearing loss cause sensory neural hearing loss
(SNHL) and not conductive hearing loss.
Otosclerosis is caused by bony overgrowth involving the enchondral layer of the bony otic capsule. It presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and can worsen with stress and hormonal changes like during pregnancy and menopause.
Stapedial otosclerosis is the most common type of otosclerosis. Here the lesion starts just in front of the oval window in an area called fistula ante fenestrae.
The presence of a reddish hue on the promontory through the tympanic membrane, known as the Schwartze sign, suggests an active focus. PTA shows loss of air conduction with air-bone gap, more for lower frequencies and Carhart's notch may be seen. Tympanometry shows an As type of tympanogram in which there is reduced compliance at or near the ambient air pressure.
Medical management with sodium fluoride is used in the active stage. Definitive treatment is stapedectomy/stapedotomy with the placement of a prosthesis. Carhart notch usually disappears
after a successful stapedectomy. Other options:
Option A: Ototoxicity causes SNHL and shows a high-frequency hearing loss in the SNHL curve.
Option B: In Meniere's disease, pure tone audiometry shows an SNHL pattern with a rising curve in the early stages (as lower frequencies are involved first) and as the disease progresses higher frequencies are involved, the curve becomes flat or a falling type.
Option D: Noise-induced hearing loss is SNHL and PTA shows a characteristic acoustic dip at 4000 Hz both for air and bone conduction.

Summating potential in electrocochleography indicates the sum of electrical activity in hair cells within the organ of Corti.
Electrocochleography (ECoG) is an objective test which records the electrical activity of the cochlea and 8th nerve in response to auditory stimuli. The recording electrode is passed through the tympanic membrane to rest over the promontory.
The three parameters measured in ECoG are:
Cochlear microphonics – measures the electrical activity that follows the stimulus and reflects the instantaneous displacement of the basilar membrane.
Summating potential (SP) – measures the electrical activity of the hair cells within the organ of Corti.
Action potential (AP) – electrical activity in the distal part of the auditory nerve. Normal SP: AP ratio is <30% but it is increased in Meniere’s disease.

The generators of ABEPs (Auditory nerve and brainstem evoked potentials) have been the subject of much research and controversy and are still not entirely agreed upon.
The literature available to us states the following:
Scott Brown's Otorhinolaryngology- wave IV–V complex probably arises from neural activity within the superior olivary complex and nuclei of the lateral lemniscus, possibly some contribution from the inferior colliculus. So lateral lemniscus is the better option.
Current Diagnosis and Treatment in Otorhinolaryngology- auditory brainstem response waves 2, 3, 4, and 5 represent the sequential activation of neurons as the signal is passed up the brainstem from the proximal part of the cochlear nerve, cochlear nucleus, superior olivary complex, and lateral lemniscus.
NIH Journals- generation of wave V reflects the activity of multiple anatomic auditory structures. A sharp positive peak of wave V arises mainly from the lateral lemniscus, following a slow negative wave represents dendritic potential in the inferior colliculus.

Solution to Question 18:
In caloric testing, cold water irrigation produces horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side of irrigation. The direction of nystagmus can be remembered by the mnemonic, COWS (cold–opposite, warm–same).
The mechanism for the nystagmus is the creation of a temperature gradient by the cold water, which pulls the cupula away from the utricle, causing nystagmus towards the oppsite side. As the horizontal semicircular canal is closer to the outer ear canal, most of the response comes from it and the nystagmus is horizontal.
The Fitzgerald–Hallpike test (bithermal caloric test) is done to assess this phenomenon. The patient lies in a supine position with head tilted forward at a 30° angle, ensuring the horizontal canal becomes vertical. Alternatingly, water at temperatures of 30°C and 44°C (7° below and above normal body temperature, respectively) is irrigated into the ears for a duration of 40 seconds each. The examiner closely observes the patient's eyes for the emergence of nystagmus until its endpoint is reached. The time taken from the start of irrigation to the endpoint of nystagmus is recorded and plotted on a calorigram.
If no nystagmus is evoked from either ear, the test is repeated with water at a temperature of 20°C for a duration of 4 minutes before labeling the labyrinth dead. A 5-minute interval should be allowed between testing each ear to ensure accurate results.

Solution to Question 11:
Rhinitis sicca affects the anterior 1/3rd of the nose since this part is exposed to the effect of the dry, dusty air.
Rhinitis sicca is a crust-forming disease seen in patients who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings, e.g. bakers, iron- and goldsmiths. It is usually confined to the anterior third of the nose particularly of the nasal septum. The ciliated columnar epithelium undergoes squamous metaplasia with atrophy of the seromucinous glands.
Treatment consists of correcting occupational surroundings and application of bland ointment with an antibiotic and steroid combination to the affected part.
Solution to Question 12:
Rhinitis caseosa is a unilateral condition and not bilateral.
It is also known as nasal cholesteatoma and is more common in males. There will be an accumulation of secretions in the nasal cavity which undergoes putrefaction resulting in the formation of caseous material. It is usually associated with suppurative sinusitis.
Treatment includes the removal of debris and granulation tissue and free drainage of the affected sinus.
Solution to Question 13:
Allergic rhinitis is an IgE-mediated immunologic response of nasal mucosa to airborne allergens.
Patients typically present with recurrent bouts of sneezing, nasal obstruction, watery nasal discharge, and itching and clinical signs include allergic shiners (dark circles around the eyes) and allergic salute (black transverse nasal crease on the dorsum of the nose due to repeated upward rubbing).
Treatment options include:
Avoidance of the allergen
Treatment with drugs like oral antihistamines, intranasal corticosteroids, intranasal cromolyn sodium
Immunotherapy is through the delivery of allergen in gradual increasing doses till the maintenance dose is reached. It suppresses the development of IgE. It has to be given for a year to see significant improvement in symptoms.
Intranasal corticosteroids (INCS) remain the preferred monotherapy for persistent allergic rhinitis (AR). However, additional studies support the additive benefit of combination treatment with INCS and intranasal antihistamines in AR. For patients receiving INCS, an intranasal decongestant may be added to the treatment for up to 4 weeks.

Option A: Dennie-Morgan lines - transverse skin creases in the infraorbital area.

Option B: Allergic salute - is a transverse nasal crease that appears as a black line across the middle of the dorsum of the nose due to constant upward rubbing of nose simulating a salute.

Option D: Serous otitis media occurs as a result of eustachian tube blockage.

Crusts that bleed on removal and atrophied turbinates are features seen in atrophic rhinitis.

Solution to Question 16:
Vidian neurectomy is a treatment option in vasomotor rhinitis.
Vasomotor rhinitis is a non-allergic condition that occurs due to parasympathetic overactivity, causing vasodilatation and congestion of nasal mucosa. The vidian nerve carries the parasympathetic supply to the nose.
The usual presentation is excessive rhinorrhea, sneezing, and nasal obstruction which is similar to allergic rhinitis. But the turbinates will be congested and edematous.
Treatment includes antihistamines, oral nasal decongestants, and topical steroids. In case of failed medical treatment, vidian neurectomy is done.
Solution to Question 17:
Rhinitis medicamentosa is caused by the prolonged use of nasal decongestants.
The treatment includes the withdrawal of nasal decongestant drops, a short course of systemic steroid therapy, and in some cases, surgical reduction of turbinates if they have become hypertrophied.
Solution to Question 18:
Complete closure of the nostrils (Young's operation) or partial closure of the nostrils (Modified Young's operation) is done for the treatment of atrophic rhinitis.
In Young's operation, both nostrils are closed completely by raising flaps within the nasal vestibule. They are opened after 6 months. During this time, the mucosa becomes normal, and the crusting is reduced.
In Modified Young's operation, the procedure has been modified to avoid discomfort from complete closure of the nostrils. Here the nostrils are only partially closed. The results are the same when compared to Young's operation.
Atrophic rhinitis (ozaena) is a chronic inflammation of the nose with atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. Roomy nasal cavities with foul-smelling crusts are seen. The patient presents with a foul smell from the nose, marked anosmia (merciful anosmia), and paradoxical nasal obstruction (nasal obstruction despite wide nasal passages). Paradoxical nasal obstruction occurs due to degenerative changes in the sensory nerves of the nasal mucosa, leading to an inability to sense airflow.
Medical management includes nasal irrigation and removal of crusts. 25% glucose in glycerine, antibiotics (quinolones or metronidazole), estradiol nasal spray, and mucolytics can be used.

When air passes through the nasal valve area which is the narrowest region of the nasal cavity, velocity increases. This creates a negative pressure that sucks mucosa of sinuses into the nasal cavity leading to polyp formation.

Solution to Question 4:
The ideal time for reduction of fracture of the nasal bone is 5-7 days following injury, once the edema has subsided.
The presence of edema interferes with the accurate reduction of the fracture. In most cases, the deformity is due to edema. So, ice packs and head elevation are advised initially after injury. After 3-5 days, the edema would subside and the underlying deformity will be apparent on clinical assessment.
After 2 weeks it is difficult to reduce since the process of callus formation and the bony and fibrous union would have started.

Restricted ocular movements, due to entrapment of inferior rectus muscle. It may cause diplopia.

Solution to Question 17:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea and fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid is the most common cause for this.
Causes of CSF rhinorrhea:
Trauma (accidental or surgical) - most of the cases follow trauma. Surgical trauma includes endoscopic sinus surgery, trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy, nasal polypectomy, or skull base surgery.
Inflammations - mucoceles of sinuses, sinonasal polyposis, the fungal infection of sinuses and osteomyelitis, can all erode the bone and dura.
Neoplasms - tumours, both benign and malignant, invading the skull base.
Congenital lesions - meningocele, meningoencephaloceles, and gliomas can have associated skull base defects.
Idiopathic - where the cause is unknown and the patient has a spontaneous leak.
Solution to Question 18:
Le-Fort I fracture is not associated with CSF rhinorrhea. Whereas, fractures like Le-Fort II, III and naso-orbito-ethmoid fracture are associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Solution to Question 19:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea secondary to surgery. Identifying features of CSF Rhinorrhea:
The CSF discharge is thin, watery, and clear in appearance.
It cannot be sniffed back. (Option D)
It does not stiffen a handkerchief.
It shows positional variation: The watery CSF discharge occurs suddenly and gushes in drops only on bending the head forward/straining.
The Halo sign is a marker of CSF rhinorrhea post-head trauma. It is considered positive when a clear ring surrounds a central bloody spot after the discharge is dropped on a handkerchief/paper towel.
Reservoir sign: The discharge is seen on rising in the morning and bending the head, as fluid accumulated in the sinuses empties into the nose.
Solution to Question 20:
Presence of  2 transferrin protein in the nasal discharge confirms the presence of CSF in the specimen.
 2 transferrin protein detection by electrophoresis is a sensitive and specific test for CSF. It is secreted by meninges and choroid plexus.
Since it is absent in nasal secretions it helps to differentiate CSF from nasal secretions. It is also present in aqueous humor and perilymph.
Another method is glucose testing by oxidase peroxidase or biochemical estimation. CSF glucose is 60% of blood glucose whereas it is <10mg/dl in nasal secretions. It is not reliable in associated meningitis (reduced levels giving false-negative results) and when CSF is mixed with blood.
Solution to Question 21:
Double ring sign is present in a case of CSF rhinorrhea.
Double ring sign or Halo sign or Target sign - when CSF mixed with blood is collected on a piece of filter paper, it will show a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.
Option A: Fracture cribriform plate of ethmoid is the most common cause. Option B: CSF glucose is 60% of blood glucose.
Option C: Intrathecal fluorescein study is used to detect the site of leak of CSF.
Solution to Question 22:
Patients with CSF rhinorrhea who are stable, are managed conservatively. The conservative measures are:
Bed rest
Elevation of the head end
Stool softeners
Avoidance of nose-blowing, sneezing, and straining.
Prophylactic antibiotics can be used to prevent meningitis and acetazolamide to decrease CSF formation. Surgery is done if the conservative management fails.

Solution to Question 1:

Adenoids are comprised of vertical ridges of lymphoid tissues separated by deep clefts. They form the superior aspect of Waldeyer's ring. They have no crypts and no capsule, unlike palatine tonsils which have both.
It is present at birth, enlarges up to the age of 6 years, and then starts regressing from puberty. It completely disappears by the age of 20 years.

Clinical features:
Nasal obstruction is the most common symptom. This leads to mouth breathing. Nasal bstruction also interferes with feeding or suckling in a child. As respiration and feeding cannot take place simultaneously, a child with adenoid enlargement fails to thrive.
Nasal discharge, sinusitis, and epistaxis.
Bilateral conductive hearing loss and serous otitis media due to eustachian tube obstruction.
Rhinolalia clausa - hyponasal voice.
Adenoid facies - elongated face with a dull expression, pinched up nose, absent nasolabial crease, pen mouth, prominent and crowded upper teeth.

(quinsy).

When symptoms of adenoid hypertrophy are not marked, breathing exercises, decongestant nasal drops, and antihistamines for any coexisting nasal allergy can cure the condition without resorting to surgery.
Marked adenoid hypertrophy with associated complications can be treated with adenoidectomy and grommet insertion.
Solution to Question 6:
Multiple adenoids is not an indication for adenoidectomy. Indications of adenoidectomy:
Adenoid hypertrophy causing snoring, mouth breathing, sleep apnoea syndrome or speech abnormalities, i.e. (rhinolalia clausa)

Velopharyngeal insufficiency is a condition where the soft palate does not close tightly against the back of the throat. This leads to air coming out the nose (characterized by hypernasality) during speech.
Contraindications for adenoidectomy:
Cleft palate or submucous palate.
Hemorrhagic diathesis.
Acute infection of the upper respiratory tract.
Solution to Question 8:

A grommet is inserted to provide continued aeration of middle ear and used in cases where fluid collection recurs.

Solution to Question 9:
Grisel syndrome involves paraspinal muscle spasm that occurs post adenoidectomy.
Grisel syndrome refers to non-traumatic atlantoaxial joint subluxation. The patient complains of neck pain and develops torticollis. It is mostly due to spasm of paraspinal muscles but can also be due to atlantoaxial dislocation requiring cervical collar and even traction.
Solution to Question 10:
Thornwaldt cyst is located in the midline of the posterior wall of the nasopharynx in the adenoid mass.
It is an epithelial-lined median recess found within the adenoid mass and extends from pharyngeal mucosa to the periosteum of the basiocciput. It represents the attachment of notochord to the pharyngeal endoderm during embryonic life.
When infected, it may be the cause of persistent postnasal discharge or crusting. Sometimes an abscess can form in the bursa (Thornwaldt’s disease). It is managed surgically by marsupialization of the swelling and complete removal of the lining of the cyst.

Solution to Question 11:
Antitubercular treatment has no role in the treatment of Thornwaldt’s abscess.
Thornwaldt’s abscess is formed due to the infection of Thornwaldt cyst. Treatment includes administration of antibiotics to treat the infection and marsupialization of the cystic swelling. There should be adequate removal of its lining membrane.

Fever, sore throat, torticollis (caused by spasm of the prevertebral muscles), and signs of systemic toxicity are common features.
Diagnosis can be established using a contrast-enhanced CT scan (CECT). If there is suspicion of thrombosis of the internal jugular vein or an aneurysm of the internal carotid artery, magnetic resonance arteriography (MRA) can be useful.
Patients require intravenous antibiotic therapy with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, carbapenem antibiotics plus drugs that target anaerobic organisms, such as clindamycin or metronidazole. A parapharyngeal abscess is drained by an external horizontal incision made on the skin a few centimeters below the angle of the mandible.

The above clinical scenario is suggestive of a parotid abscess and excessive gland stimulation is not a cause for its formation.
Etiology of Parotid Abscess:
Dehydration, particularly in postsurgical cases (5-7 post-op days) and debilitated patients, with stasis of salivary flow is the predisposing cause.
Infection from the oral cavity travels via the Stenson’s duct to invade the parotid gland (retrograde spread of infection). The most common organism is Staphylococcus aureus but Streptococci, anaerobic organisms, and rarely the gram negative organisms have also been cultured.
Solution to Question 20:
In a case of a parotid abscess, one must never wait for fluctuation or pus point to occur. This is because the superficial layer of parotidomasseteric fascia is tense and the fluctuation will be apparent only in later stages.
A parotid abscess refers to an infection and pus formation in the parotid space. It is caused most commonly by Staphylococcus aureus. Post-surgical cases and debilitated patients with stasis of salivary flow are at risk of developing parotid abscesses.
Patients typically present with unilateral swelling, redness, induration, and tenderness over the parotid gland and angle of the mandible. Dehydration and fever are also present. Diagnosis is by ultrasonography or a CT scan. Multiple small loculi of pus are seen in the parenchyma. Aspiration of abscess can be done to determine the culture and sensitivity of the infective agent.
Correction of dehydration, improving oral hygiene and promoting salivary flow. Intravenous antibiotics are also used in treatment.
Surgical drainage under local or general anesthesia is carried out by a preauricular incision as employed for parotidectomy. A skin flap is raised to expose the surface of the gland, and the abscess or abscesses are bluntly opened working parallel to the branches of the VIIth nerve. The skin incision is loosely approximated over a drain and allowed to heal by secondary intention.

The sternohyoid is not responsible for upward movement (elevation). It is a depressor of the larynx.

Easy to remember: Check the other attachment(non-laryngeal side). If it's above the level of the hyoid, the muscle is an elevator. If it's below the level of the hyoid, it’s a depressor.

Most of the laryngeal foreign bodies are arrested above the vocal cords, i.e. above the middle of the thyroid cartilage. Thus, an effective airway can be provided by piercing the cricothyroid membrane.

Solution to Question 1:
Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions. It is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi such as bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.
Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea like laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.
Stridor is an audible respiratory noise that gets produced by turbulent airflow through an obstructed upper airway. It is an inspiratory sound that may have an expiratory component. It is distinct from stertor which is a snoring-like noise produced from an obstructed nasopharynx or oropharynx.
The intensity and pitch of sounds originating from the respiratory system vary based on their site of origin within the respiratory tract and may be heard with or without a stethoscope. Usually, the pitch of the sound increases, and the intensity decreases as one goes lower into the respiratory tract.

Solution to Question 2:
Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor.
It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration producing stridor and sometimes cyanosis.
It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor improves (decreases) in the prone position, worsens during feeding. The cry is normal. On examination, omega-shaped epiglottis is seen.

Solution to Question 3:

The clinical picture and omega-shaped epiglottis are suggestive of laryngomalacia. Conservative treatment is preferred for laryngomalacia as this condition self-corrects by two years of age.

Solution to Question 6:
Myer Cotton’s grading is used for subglottic stenosis.
It is the abnormal thickening of cricoid/fibrous tissue proliferation below cords. It causes the airway to narrow and presents with dyspnea, biphasic stridor and a normal cry.
Diagnosis:
In full-term infants, subglottic diameter <4mm.
In premature infants, subglottic diameter <3mm.
The Myer Cotton’s grading system allows to stratify the stenosis and plan for treatment:
Grade 1: <50% stenosis
Grade 2: 51-70% stenosis
Grade 3: 71-99% stenosis
Grade 4: No lumen detected Other options
Option A - Hyams grading is a predictive tool used in olfactory neuroblastoma.
Option B - House Brackmann grading is used as a facial nerve grading system.
Option D - Modified mallampati classification is used to assess difficult airway

On compressing the swelling, there is a gurgling/hissing sound known as Bryce’s sign. The given clinical picture with a positive Bryce sign is suggestive of laryngocele.
Laryngocele is an air-filled cavity within the larynx developing from the saccule. The patient presents with a neck swelling that is soft and compressible.
Options A: Branchial cleft cysts does not move with deglutition.
Option C: Cystic hygroma does not move with deglutition and usually presents before 2 years. Option D: Thyroglossal cyst presents as a midline swelling.
Solution to Question 8:
Laryngocele arises from the saccule of the ventricle. It is an abnormal dilation of the laryngeal saccule and extends beyond the thyroid cartilage and the ventricle.
It is seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to raised transglottic air pressure. It can be internal, external, or combined. External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck which increases in size on coughing or performing Valsalva maneuver.
Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization. External laryngocele is managed by excision
(external/LASER).

The given clinical picture is of congenital subglottic hemangioma. Embolization is not preferred in congenital laryngeal conditions. All congenital laryngeal conditions tend to regress with growth.
The principal management is conservative as many hemangiomas involute spontaneously. Depending on the status of the airway, treatment can involve:
To wait and watch
Steroid therapy
Tracheostomy and observation
If the condition does not regress with time, the modalities of treatment include:
LASER excision
Laryngofissure and excision
-pexy and -plasty procedures (epiglottopexy, supraglottoplasty, etc)

Laryngeal cysts arise in the aryepiglottic folds.
These are benign conditions that need no intervention unless they are large. Large cysts can cause airway obstruction/change in voice. These require immediate aspiration followed by deroofing.
Solution to Question 11:
The image showing grape-like projections, involving the anterior part of the vocal cords depicts a laryngeal papilloma.
Laryngeal papilloma is a benign tumor of the larynx caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV type 6 and 11). They can occur in children, most commonly around 3 -5 years of age (juvenile papillomatosis), as well as in adults. They involve the supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx. Seeding of the lesions can occur during invasive laryngeal procedures, such as intubation. They have a high recurrence rate and very low potential for malignancy.
Adult-onset laryngeal papillomatosis is less common and usually seen in males aged 30-50 years. It is less aggressive and involves the anterior part of the vocal cords. The treatment is the same as juvenile papillomatosis.
Patients present with hoarseness, aphonia, dyspnea, or stridor. Laryngoscopy shows pinkish to white grape-like projections that can be sessile or pedunculate with a visible central vascular core. The diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy. Treatment consists
of micro-laryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision.
The image below depicts laryngeal papillomatosis on laryngoscopy:

Solution to Question 12:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with chronic hoarseness (3 months) of voice and respiratory distress for 2 weeks suggests the diagnosis of respiratory papillomatosis (juvenile papillomatosis).
Croup (Option A) and acute epiglottitis (Option D), which cause acute upper respiratory tract obstruction, are ruled out due to the chronic nature of the symptoms. In croup, the upper airway obstruction becomes apparent after 1 to 3 days of low-grade fever, rhinorrhea, and pharyngitis. On the other hand, in epiglottitis, a child experiences respiratory distress within hours of developing a fever.
Vocal nodules (Option C) are not typically associated with respiratory distress.
Respiratory papillomatosis is the most common respiratory tract neoplasm in children. They are simple warts (benign tumors) caused by human papillomavirus types 6 and 11 commonly seen in children aged 3 to 5 years.
The course involves remissions and exacerbations of recurrent papillomas, mostly affecting the glottic area (vocal cords), and supraglottis. The patient presents with progressively worsening hoarseness, sleep-disordered breathing, dyspnea, stridor, and severe airway obstruction if left untreated.
Diagnosis confirmed by direct laryngoscopy, which shows grape-like projections (shown below), and biopsy. Treatment consists of micro laryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision. Antivirals like interferon alpha2a, ribavirin, cidofovir, and acyclovir are used as adjunct therapies.

Other options:
Option A: Croup (laryngotracheobronchitis) is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The patient initially presents with an upper respiratory tract infection (rhinorrhea, pharyngitis, cough,
low-grade fever) followed by a characteristic barking cough, hoarseness, and inspiratory stridor.
Option C: Vocal nodule (singer’s or screamer's nodule) occurs as a result of chronic vocal abuse. They appear symmetrically at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two third of the v cal cord. The patient presents with chronic hoarseness and voice fatigue.
The image below shows symmetric vocal nodules:

Option D: Acute epiglottitis is caused by streptococcus pyogenes, pneumococci, Hemophilus influenzae, and staphylococcus aureus. It is characterized by an acute rapidly progressive course of high-grade fever, dyspnea, and stridor.

Solution to Question 1:
Dysphonia plica ventricularis is a low-pitched voice produced by the vestibular folds.
It can either be due to functional voice misuse or due to organic lesions like fixation of the true vocal cord. It is characterized by a low-pitched, rough and strained voice.
Treatment includes voice therapy and psychological counseling.
Solution to Question 2:
Spasmodic dysphonia is not only a local laryngeal disorder. It is associated with many neurological conditions too.
There are 2 types of spasmodic dysphonia:
Adductor dysphonia
The adductor muscles of the larynx go into spasm causing vocal cords to go into adduction. The voice becomes strained/strangled.
Treatment consists of botulinum toxin injections in the thyroarytenoid muscles on one or both sides to relieve the spasm.
Abductor dysphonia
It is due to the spasm of the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle and thus the glottis is kept open.
The patient gets a breathy voice or breathy breaks in voice.
Treatment consists of botulinum toxin injections in posterior cricoarytenoid muscles. Patients who do not respond to toxin injection can be treated by type 1 thyroplasty or fat injection.
Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical picture represents that of functional aphonia. In this condition, vocal cords are normal.
Functional aphonia or hysterical aphonia is mostly seen in emotionally labile females in the age group of 15-30 years. Aphonia is usually sudden and unaccompanied by other laryngeal symptoms.
Treatment is to reassure the patient of normal laryngeal function and psychotherapy.
Solution to Question 4:
The given clinical scenario with a positive Gutzmann’s pressure test is suggestive of puberphonia.
It is a condition seen in emotionally labile adolescent males. They continue to speak in the prepubertal high pitched voice.
Gutzmann's pressure test is positive when pressing the thyroid prominence in a backward and downward direction relaxes the overstretched cords and produces a low tone voice. The treatment is speech therapy.
Solution to Question 5:
Phonasthenia is the condition seen in this patient. The clinical scenario of voice overuse and keyhole appearance of glottis point to this diagnosis. Here, both thyroarytenoid and inter arytenoid muscles are involved.
Phonasthenia is the weakness of voice due to fatigue of laryngeal muscles. This leads to a phonatory gap. The shape of the gap depends on the muscle involved:
Thyroarytenoid alone: elliptical space
Interarytenoid alone: triangular space
Both thyroarytenoid and interarytenoid: keyhole appearance

Solution to Question 7:
Common cold leads to rhinolalia clausa. A large nasopharynx doesn't cause rhinolalia clausa but instead rhinolalia aperta.
Rhinolalia clausa or hyponasality is a lack of nasal resonance for words that are resonated in the nasal cavity. Words with M, N, NG sounds like B, D, G. It is due to the blockage of the nose or nasopharynx.
Common causes of rhinolalia clausa are:

Nasal polypi
Nasal growth
Adenoids
Nasopharyngeal mass
Familial speech pattern.
Solution to Question 8:
Rhinolalia aperta or hypernasality of speech will be seen in this condition of cleft palate.
It is seen when certain words which have little nasal resonance are resonated through the nose. The defect is the failure of the nasopharynx to cut off from the oropharynx or abnormal communication between the oral and nasal cavities.
Common causes are:
Velopharyngeal insufficiency
Congenitally short soft palate
Submucous palate
Large nasopharynx
Cleft of soft palate
Paralysis of soft palate
Post adenoidectomy
Oronasal fistula
Familial speech pattern
Habitual speech pattern. NOTE:
Clausa = Close; closed nose and nasopharynx
Aperta = Open/aperture; abnormally open nose and nasopharynx
Solution to Question 9:
Wagner and Grossman hypothesis
Explains the position of the cord in recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) palsy.
States that “The complete paralysis of the recurrent laryngeal nerve results in paramedian cord due to the adduction by intact cricothyroid muscle”.
Since cricothyroid is supplied by SLN, it is spared and causes mild adduction.
Solution to Question 10:

Above the vocal cords, the larynx is supplied by the internal laryngeal nerve- a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.

A  the other muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

Posterior cricoarytenoid is the only intrinsic muscle of the larynx that causes abduction of the vocal cords.
Solution to Question 13:
Intermediate (cadaveric) position is seen in complete paralysis of the vocal cord.
This is a neutral position of the cricoarytenoid joint.
Abduction and adduction take place from this position.
It is not always seen in cadavers (misnomer).
Solution to Question 14:
Surgical trauma is the most common cause of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis.
The incidence of permanent RLN paralysis is approximately 1% to 1.5% for total thyroidectomy and less for near-total procedures.
Note: Previously, extra laryngeal malignancies had been the most common cause which included lung (50%), esophagus, thyroid, and larynx.
Solution to Question 15:
Ortner's syndrome is a rare cause of left (unilateral) recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy due to compression by enlarged cardiac structures such as the left atrium or pulmonary artery.
Causes of recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy:
Thyroid surgery
Neck trauma
Thyroid malignancy
Cervical lymphadenopathy.
Though the risk of bilateral nerve involvement is much less than unilateral, it is possible. Depending on whether the palsy is unilateral or bilateral, findings will differ.
Terminologies in vocal cord palsy:
Pure RLN palsy: abductor palsy (the only abductor, posterior cricoarytenoid is affected)
Pure SLN palsy: rare (only cricothyroid, one of the adductors and the main tensor is affected)
Complete paralysis: both SLN and RLN are involved.

Solution to Question 17:
The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is more prone to injury, causing vocal cord paralysis. The reasons being:
It is longer as it loops around the arch of the aorta to climb back to the larynx.
It is in association with more structures in the mediastinum. Other options:
Right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the subclavian artery and therefore it’s shorter and safer.
Unilateral paralysis of the superior laryngeal nerve is rare and they are usually a part of a combined paralysis.
Solution to Question 18:
The above clinical picture of stridor and dyspnea with a normal voice is most likely due to bilateral abductor paralysis (B/L RLN injury). It is the most dangerous vocal cord lesion.
A the other options will have an abnormality in the voice. Normal voice is seen only in B/L RLN injury.
In bilateral abductor paralysis,
Both the cords lie in the median or paramedian position, the airway is inadequate causing dyspnea and stridor. This may lead to death if untreated.
The voice is good.
Dyspnea and stridor become worse on exertion or during an attack of acute laryngitis.
Solution to Question 19:
The clinical presentation is that of bilateral complete palsy (SLN + RLN).
Both cords are in a cadaveric position, the patient has aphonia but respiration is maintained. Aphonia is suggestive of bilateral complete palsy, unilateral palsy presents with hoarseness of voice. Sensations are lost from supraglottis (supplied by the internal branch of SLN), the patient will develop aspiration and multiple chest infections.

Paralysis of cricothyroid is responsible for the difficulty in raising the pitch of her voice.
Cricothyroid is the main tensor of the vocal cords. It is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve
(branch of the superior laryngeal nerve).

Solution to Question 2:
Glottic carcinoma presents with hoarseness of voice as its earliest symptom. Lesions of the vocal cords affect its vibratory capacity. Therefore they are diagnosed early and have a better prognosis.
Supraglottic and subglottic growths are often silent. Hoarseness is a late symptom.
Solution to Question 3:
Phonotrauma is not the reason behind the development of hoarseness of voice in laryngeal carcinoma. It occurs due to overuse of voice and is associated with the development of benign lesions such as vocal nodules and cysts.
Hoarseness in supraglottic cancer and subglottic cancer indicates spread of disease to:
Vocal cords with infiltration of the thyroarytenoid muscle
Involvement of recurrent laryngeal nerve
Cricoarytenoid joint involvement.
Hoarseness in glottic carcinoma is early because lesions of the cord affect its vibratory capacity.
Solution to Question 4:
Tumours limited to the glottis usually do not spread to any lymph node station as there are no lymphatics in the vocal cords.
However, if the tumour invades the supra- or the infra- glottic spaces, lymph node spread can occur.
Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumour of the larynx. Glottis is the most common site of cancer.
Solution to Question 5:
Supraglottic carcinoma has the highest chance of lymphatic spread in the larynx.
Lymph node enlargement is often a presenting complaint as it occurs early in the course of the disease.
Solution to Question 6:
The Pyriform sinus is not a subsite of the supraglottis.
Epiglottis, false cords, aryepiglottic folds (medial wall of the pyriform sinus), and arytenoids are the subsites of supraglottis.
Aryepiglottic folds are shared between the supraglottis and hypopharynx.
Solution to Question 7:
Level II (upper jugular) and III (middle jugular) lymph nodes are the most common and earliest nodes involved in supraglottic carcinoma.
Solution to Question 8:
Hoarseness of voice is a late symptom of supraglottic carcinoma.
The most common site of supraglottic carcinoma is the epiglottis followed by false cords and then aryepiglottic folds. Nodal metastases occur early to the upper and middle jugular lymph
nodes. Bilateral metastases can be seen in cases of epiglottic cancer. Supraglottic growths are often silent as hoarseness is a late symptom.
Solution to Question 9:
Endoscopic resection with CO2 laser is most commonly used in laryngeal surgeries.
Carcinoma of the mobile membranous vocal cords can be precisely excised with the CO2 laser under the microscope. It gives the same result as being traditionally treated with radiotherapy. Laser excision has the advantage of lower cost, lower duration of treatment, and morbidity.

Solution to Question 11:
Tumour limited to both vocal cords with normal mobility can be classified as stage T1b. Treatment will include radiotherapy or transoral laser microsurgery. There is no indication for a total laryngectomy.
Total laryngectomy is indicated in:
All T4 lesions
Invasion of thyroid or cricoid cartilage
Bilateral arytenoid cartilage involvement
Lesions of the posterior commissure
Failure after radiotherapy or conservation surgery
Transglottic cancers with cord fixation.
It is contraindicated in patients with distant metastasis.
Treatment of T3 cancers is controversial, open vertical hemilaryngectomy and more
extensive partial laryngectomies are used in carefully selected cases. Total laryngectomy or CRT is recommended for bulky T3 tumors or tumors not suitable for conservation laryngeal surgery.

Solution to Question 13:
Laryngeal carcinoma is an indication of high tracheostomy. It is done at the level of the 1st tracheal ring and an opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland.
The disadvantage of a high tracheostomy is subglottic stenosis at the level of the cricoid and perichondritis of the cricoid. However, in laryngeal carcinoma this would be a temporary measure as the definitive management is total laryngectomy.
Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea.
Functions:
Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction.
Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space by 30-50% and reducing airway resistance
Uses a cuff to protect the airways from secretions and blood
Allows suction of secretions in the setting of the impaired cough reflex.
Allows positive pressure respiration
Allows administration of anesthesia Indications:
Respiratory obstruction due to
Infections (laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis, epiglottitis)
Trauma due to external injury, mandibular or maxillofacial fractures
Neoplasms
Foreign bodies or edema
Bilateral abductor paralysis
Congenital anomalies
Retained secretions
Inability to cough due to coma, spasm, or paralysis of respiratory muscles
Aspiration of pharyngeal secretions
Painful cough
Respiratory insufficiency due to emphysema, chronic bronchitis

Solution to Question 3:
Lempert’s trocar does not exist.
Option A: Lempert’s curette (scoop) is used for removal of bony septa and granulations in mastoid surgery.

Option B: Lempert’s endaural retractor is used for endaural approach to ear surgery. It has two lateral blades which retract the flaps and a third central blade with holes. The central blade retracts the temporalis muscle. The central blade can be fixed to the body of the retractor by its hole.

Option C: Lempert’s endaural speculum is used to spread open the meatus when giving the local injection or making an endaural incision.

Lempert’s incision is used in endaural approach. It consists of two parts:
Lempert I: It is a semicircular incision, made from 12 o’clock to 6 o’clock position in the posterior meatal wall at the bony-cartilaginous junction.
Lempert II: Starts from the first incision at 12 o’clock and then passes upwards in a curvilinear fashion between tragus and the crus of helix. It passes through the incisura terminalis and thus does not cut the cartilage.
Both mastoid and external canal surgery can be done.

Note:
Trephination (also known as trepanning or burr holing) is a surgical intervention where a hole is drilled, incised or scraped into the skull using simple surgical tools. Trephination of frontal sinus is done for acute frontal sinusitis if there is persistence or exacerbation of pain or pyrexia in spite of medical treatment for 48 h or if the lid swelling is increasing and threatening orbital cellulitis.
Solution to Question 9:
The image is of a Digital audiometer.
An audiometer is an electronic device that produces pure tones, which can be increased or decreased in 5 dB steps. The amount of intensity that has to be raised above the normal level is a measure of the degree of hearing loss at that frequency. This is charted in the form of a graph
called an audiogram.
The difference in the thresholds of air and bone conduction (A–B gap) is a measure of the degree of conductive deafness.
Uses:
To measure the threshold of hearing of air and bone conduction
Helps to predict speech reception threshold
To diagnose the type of hearing loss and measure the degree
For the prescription of hearing aids
Helps to find the degree of handicap for medicolegal purposes
A record can be kept for future reference.
Solution to Question 10:
The image is of a tympanometer. It is used in evaluating the status of the middle ear.
It is based on a simple principle that when a sound strikes the tympanic membrane, some of the sound energy is absorbed while the rest is reflected. A stiffer tympanic membrane would reflect more sound energy than a compliant one.
